revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox film | name = Night at the Museum:
Secret of the Tomb | image = Night at the Museum Secret of the Tomb poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Shawn Levy]] | producer = {{plainlist| *Shawn Levy *[[Chris Columbus (filmmaker)|Chris Columbus]] *Mark Radcliffe}} | screenplay = {{plainlist| *David Guion *Michael Handelman}} | story = {{plainlist| *Mark Friedman *David Guion *Michael Handelman}} | based on = {{based on|Characters|[[Thomas Lennon (actor)|Thomas Lennon]]
[[Robert Ben Garant]]}} | starring = {{plainlist| *[[Ben Stiller]] *[[Robin Williams]] *[[Owen Wilson]] *[[Dan Stevens]] *[[Ben Kingsley]]}} | music = [[Alan Silvestri]] | cinematography = [[Guillermo Navarro]] | editing = Dean Zimmerman | studio = {{plainlist| *[[21 Laps Entertainment]] *[[1492 Pictures]] *[[TSG Entertainment]]}} | distributor = [[20th Century Fox]] | released = {{Film date|2014|12|11|[[Ziegfeld Theatre (1969)|Ziegfeld Theatre]]|2014|12|19|United States}} | runtime = 97 minutes{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/night-museum-secret-tomb-film | title=''NIGHT AT THE MUSEUM: SECRET OF THE TOMB'' (PG) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=December 2, 2014 | accessdate=December 2, 2014}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $127 million{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=nightatthemuseum3.htm | title=Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014) | work=[[Box Office Mojo]] | publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] | accessdate=February 18, 2016}} | gross = $363.2 million }} '''''Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb''''' is a 2014 American [[comedy film|comedy]] [[adventure film]] directed by [[Shawn Levy]] and written by David Guion and Michael Handelman. It is the third and final installment in the ''[[Night at the Museum (film series)|Night at the Museum]]'' trilogy. The film stars [[Ben Stiller]], [[Robin Williams]], [[Owen Wilson]], [[Dan Stevens]] and [[Ben Kingsley]].{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2014/07/27/night-at-the-museum-3-secret-of-the-tomb/12494557/ |title=Sneak peek: 'Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb' |newspaper=USA Today |date= |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} In ''Secret of the Tomb'', security guard Larry Daley must travel to London to return the tablet of Ahkmenrah, an Egyptian artifact which causes the exhibits to come to life, before the magic disappears. Principal photography of ''Secret of the Tomb'' took place from January to May 2014 in London, England and British Columbia, Canada. The film premiered on December 11, 2014, at New York City's [[Ziegfeld Theater]] and was released in the United States on December 19, 2014. ''Secret of the Tomb'' grossed over $363 million at the box office. This film was dedicated to the memory of Robin Williams, who died four months before the film's release, and fellow ''Night at the Museum'' actor [[Mickey Rooney]], who died before principal photography was finished. ==Plot== In 1938 [[Egypt]], a team of [[archaeology|archaeologists]] discover the tomb of [[pharaoh]] Ahkmenrah, including a young Cecil Fredericks, finding the magical Tablet of Ahkmenrah. The locals warn the group that removing the tablet will end its magic. In present-day New York City, Larry Daley remains the [[security guard|night guard]] of the [[American Museum of Natural History]]. He, [[Theodore Roosevelt]], [[Sacagawea]], [[Attila the Hun]], Jedediah, Octavius, Rexy the ''[[Tyrannosaurus rex]]'' skeleton and Dexter the [[capuchin monkey]] help re-open the Hayden Planetarium. A new wax [[Neanderthal]] resembling Larry named Laaa is introduced, identifying Larry as his father. Ahkmenrah shows Larry that the tablet is corroding, which later causes the exhibits to act erratically, causing mayhem at the planetarium's reopening. Afterwards, Larry catches his son Nick, who plans on taking a [[gap year]] to sort out his life, throwing a house party. Larry reunites with Cecil, now in retirement, who realizes the end of the tablet's magic will cause the exhibits to become lifeless. Cecil explains that Ahkmenrah's parents, Merenkahre and Shepseheret, may be able to restore the tablet's power but that they are located in the [[British Museum]]. Larry convinces the museum's curator, Dr. McPhee, to let him ship Ahkmenrah to London to restore the tablet, convinced that McPhee knows its secrets. Larry and Nick travel to the British Museum, bypassing the night guard Tilly. To Larry's surprise, Roosevelt, Sacagawea, Attila, Jed, Octavius, Dexter, Rexy and Laaa have come as well, and Laaa is left to stand guard while the others search the museum, the tablet bringing its own exhibits to life. They are joined by a wax Sir [[Lancelot]], who helps them fight off aggressive museum exhibits like a [[Xiangliu]] statue and a ''[[Triceratops]]'' [[skeleton]]. Jedediah and Octavius fall through a ventilation shaft but are rescued from an erupting [[Pompeii]] model by Dexter. The group find Ahkmenrah's parents, learning the tablet's power can be regenerated by moonlight, since it is empowered through the magic of [[Khonsu]]. Lancelot mistakes the tablet for the [[Holy Grail]] and steals it, leaving to find [[Camelot]]. Larry and Laaa are locked in the employee break room by Tilly, but they escape, and Laaa remains behind to distract Tilly, during which they become attracted to each other. Lancelot crashes a performance of the musical [[Camelot (musical)|''Camelot'']], starring [[Hugh Jackman]] and [[Alice Eve]] as [[King Arthur]] and [[Queen Guinevere]], but Larry and the others chase him to the theatre roof, where the New York exhibits begin to die. Lancelot then sees that the quest was about them and gives the tablet back. The moonlight restores the tablet's power, saving the exhibits. They decide that Ahkmenrah and the tablet should stay with his parents, even if it means the New York exhibits will no longer come to life. Back in New York, Larry spends some final moments with his friends before sunrise. Three years later, Larry, having taken the blame for the planetarium incident, thus giving McPhee his job back, now works as a teacher, and a traveling British Museum exhibit comes to New York. Tilly becomes the new night guard, and gives the tablet to Dr. McPhee, showing him its power and allowing the exhibits to awaken again to celebrate Ahkmenrah's reunion. Outside, Larry watches them party inside. ==Cast== * [[Ben Stiller]] as Larry Daley, a security guard at the [[American Museum of Natural History]].{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/01/rebel-wilson-joins-night-at-the-museum-3/ |title=Rebel Wilson Joins 'Night at the Museum 3' Cast |website=Deadline Hollywood |date= |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} ** Stiller also plays Laaa, a [[Neanderthal]] who resembles Larry. * [[Robin Williams]] as [[Theodore Roosevelt]], the [[Wax sculpture]] of the 26th President of the United States. * [[Owen Wilson]] as Jedediah, a [[cowboy]] [[diorama]] miniature. * [[Steve Coogan]] as Octavius, a [[Roman legion|Roman soldier]] miniature. * [[Ricky Gervais]] as Dr. McPhee, the director of the Museum of Natural History. * [[Rachael Harris]] as Madeline Phelps, the chairwoman of the American Museum of Natural History. * [[Dan Stevens]] as [[Lancelot|Sir Lancelot]], the wax statue of the legendary [[Round Table|Knight of the Round Table]].{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://deadline.com/2013/11/downton-abbeys-dan-stevens-in-lancelot-mode-for-night-at-the-museum-3/ |title='Downton Abbey's Dan Stevens Joins 'Night at the Museum 3' As Lancelot |website=Deadline Hollywood |date= |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} * [[Rebel Wilson]] as Tilly, the night security guard at the British Museum. * [[Skyler Gisondo]] as Nick Daley, the son of Larry Daley.{{cite web|last=Yamato |first=Jen |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/11/skyler-gisondo-lands-night-at-the-museum-3/ |title=Skyler Gisondo Set For 'Night at the Museum 3' |website=Deadline Hollywood |date= |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} He was previously played by [[Jake Cherry]] in [[Night at the Museum (film series)|the first two films]]. * [[Rami Malek]] as Ahkmenrah, the mummy of an ancient pharaoh. * [[Patrick Gallagher (actor)|Patrick Gallagher]] as [[Attila the Hun]], the statue of the leader of the Huns. * [[Mizuo Peck]] as [[Sacagawea]], the polyurethane model of the [[Lemhi Shoshone]] woman who is girlfriend of the Theodore Roosevelt sculpture. * [[Ben Kingsley]] as Merenkahre, the mummy of an ancient pharaoh and Ahkmenrah's father.{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/01/ben-kingsley-tapped-by-shawn-levy-for-night-at-the-museum-3/ |title=Ben Kingsley Joins 'Night at the Museum 3' |website=Deadline Hollywood |date= |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} * [[Dick Van Dyke]] as Cecil Fredericks, a retired security guard from the first film.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2563081/Mickey-Rooney-93-pushed-airport-wheelchair-gears-film-Night-At-The-Museum-3-Canada.html |title=Raring to go! A grinning Mickey Rooney, 93, is pushed through airport in wheelchair as he arrives in Canada to film Night at the Museum 3 |work = The Daily Mail |date=January 19, 2014 |accessdate=March 4, 2014}} ** [[Percy Hynes White]] plays the younger Cecil Fredericks * [[Mickey Rooney]] as Gus, a retired security guard from the first film. * [[Bill Cobbs]] as Reginald, a retired security guard from the first film. * [[Andrea Martin]] as Rose, an archivist at the Museum of Natural History. * [[Brennan Elliott]] as Robert Fredericks, C.J.'s father in the [[prologue]]. * [[Matt Frewer]] as Archibald Stanley, an archeologist who accompanies Robert and Cecil in the prologue. * [[Anjali Jay]] as Shepseheret, the mummy of a [[Great Royal Wife]] of Merenkahre and mother of Ahkmenrah. * [[Crystal the Monkey]] as Dexter, a [[Capuchin monkey]]. * [[Hugh Jackman]] as Himself (uncredited) * [[Alice Eve]] as Herself (uncredited) ===Voices=== * [[Robin Williams]] as [[Garuda]] Artifact. * [[Brad Garrett]] as [[Moai|Easter Island Head]]. * Regina Taufen as New York Reporter. ==Production== On January 21, 2010, co-writer [[Thomas Lennon (actor)|Thomas Lennon]] said to ''[[Access Hollywood]]'', "I think it's a really outstanding idea to do ''Night at the Museum 3'', in fact. I wonder if someone's not even already working on a script for that. I cannot confirm that for a fact, but I cannot deny it for a fact either... It might be in the works."{{cite web|url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/night-at-the-museum-3-in-the-works_article_28049 |title='Night at the Museum 3' In The Works |website=Access Hollywood |date=January 21, 2010 |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} In an October 2011 interview with ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', Stiller confirmed the sequel, however, he said that it was only in the "ideas stage".{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/ben-stiller-zoolander-tower-heist-eddie-murphy-253286 |title=Ben Stiller Reveals 'Zoolander' Sequel Secrets; Future of the Fockers and What He Thinks of 'Tower Heist' Co-Star Eddie Murphy as Oscar Host |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=October 26, 2011 |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} In February 2013 it was announced that the film, directed by Shawn Levy, would be released on December 25, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/night-at-the-museum-3-release-date-shawn-levy/|title=Shawn Levy Returns to Direct NIGHT AT THE MUSEUM 3 for December 25, 2014 Release; THE MAZE RUNNER Set to Open February 14, 2014|first=Adam|last=Chitwood|website=Collider|date=February 7, 2013|accessdate=February 8, 2013}} On September 10, 2013, it was announced that shooting would start in February 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/night-at-the-museum-3-in-the-works_article_28049 |title='Night at the Museum 3' In The Works | Access Hollywood – Celebrity News, Photos & Videos |website=Access Hollywood |date=January 21, 2010 |accessdate=October 29, 2011}} On November 8, 2013, actor [[Dan Stevens]] was cast as [[Lancelot]]. On November 15, 2013, it was announced that [[Skyler Gisondo]] would be replacing [[Jake Cherry]] in the role of Nicky Daley. On December 18, 2013, it was announced that Stiller, [[Robin Williams]], and [[Ricky Gervais]] would be returning for the sequel.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/12/ricky-gervais-reprising-in-night-at-the-museum-3/ |title=Ricky Gervais Reprising In 'Night at the Museum 3′ |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=December 18, 2011 |accessdate=December 23, 2013}} On January 9, 2014, it was announced that [[Rebel Wilson]] would play a security guard in the British Museum. On January 14, 2014, the film's release date was moved up from December 25, 2014, to December 19, 2014.{{cite web|last=Busch |first=Anita |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/01/fox-sets-date-for-untitled-planet-of-the-apes-project-poltergeist-other-pics-get-new-slots/ |title=Fox Sets Date For 'Planet of the Apes' Project, Moves Romancer 'The Longest Ride' Away From 'Fifty Shades of Grey'; 'Night at the Museum' Now Head to Head With 'The Hobbit' |website=Deadline Hollywood |date= |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} On January 23, 2014, it was announced [[Ben Kingsley]] would play an Egyptian Pharaoh at the British Museum.{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=113927 |title= Sir Ben Kingsley Joining Shawn Levy's Night at the Museum 3 |website=Comingsoon.net |date=January 23, 2014 |accessdate=January 23, 2014}} [[Principal photography]] and production began on January 27, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.studiosystemnews.com/on-the-set-for-12714 |title=On The Set For 1/27/14: Universal's 'Ouija' Wraps, 'Night at the Museum 3′ Starts For 20th Century Fox ‹ Studio System News |website=Studiosystemnews.com |date= |accessdate=January 29, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2547242/Ben-Stiller-Robin-Williams-joined-Downton-Abbeys-Dan-Stevens-film-Night-Of-The-Museum-3-London.html |title= Quiet on set! Ben Stiller and Robin Williams are joined by former Downton Abbey star Dan Stevens as they film Night at the Museum 3 in London |newspaper=The Daily Mail |date=January 28, 2014 |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} On May 6, 2014, it was announced that the film would be titled ''Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb''.{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=117900 |title=Ben Stiller's Third Franchise Adventure is Now Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb. |website=ComingSoon.net |date= |accessdate=May 6, 2014}} In May 2014, principal photography ended.{{cite web|last=Labrecque |first=Jeff |url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2014/08/11/robin-williams-last-roles/ |title=Robin Williams leaves behind four upcoming films |website=Insidemovies.ew.com |date=August 11, 2014 |accessdate=August 12, 2014}} Shooting took place outside the [[British Museum]] in [[London]], [[England]], as well as on a sound stage at the [[Vancouver Film Studios]] in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] for scenes taking place inside the museum. ==Music== [[Alan Silvestri]] returned to score the final installment of the [[Night at the Museum (film series)|trilogy]].{{cite web | url=http://www.movie-wave.net/night-at-the-museum-secret-of-the-tomb/ | title=Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb | work=movie-wave.net | accessdate=February 13, 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/12/04/night-at-the-museum-secret-of-the-tomb-soundtrack-details/ | title='Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb’ Soundtrack Details | work=filmmusicreporter.com | accessdate=February 13, 2015}} {{Infobox album | name = Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) | type = Film | artist = Alan Silvestri | cover = | alt = | released = {{Start date|2015|01|06}} | recorded = 2014 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Film score]] | length = {{Duration|m=56|s=52}} | label = Varèse Sarabande | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} ===Track listing=== [[Varèse Sarabande]] released a soundtrack album of the score on January 6, 2015.{{cite web | url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/night-at-museum-secret-tomb/id947997354 | title=Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) | work=itunes.apple.com | accessdate=February 13, 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.songonlyrics.net/soundtracks/night-atthe-museum-secretofthe-tomb-soundtracklist.html | title=Night at the Museum: Secret Of The Tomb Soundtrack List Movie (2014 | work=songonlyrics.net | accessdate=February 13, 2015}}{{cite web | url=https://www.amazon.com/Night-at-Museum-Secret-Tomb/dp/B00P11J7ZW | title=Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb Soundtrack | work=amazon.com | accessdate=February 13, 2015}} {{Track listing | headline = ''Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)'' | total_length = 56:52 | all_writing = Alan Silvestri | title1 = The Ahkmenrah Expedition | length1 = 3:34 | title2 = Performance Prep | length2 = 2:02 | title3 = LOL | length3 = 2:22 | title4 = The Grand Re-Opening | length4 = 3:13 | title5 = The End Will Come | length5 = 2:19 | title6 = Sneak And Greet | length6 = 3:25 | title7 = Sir Lancelot | length7 = 3:33 | title8 = Where Are Jed And Octavius? | length8 = 2:50 | title9 = Main Hall | length9 = 3:24 | title10 = Xiangliu | length10 = 3:46 | title11 = Male Bonding | length11 = 2:15 | title12 = The Legend of the Tablet | length12 = 3:11 | title13 = The Escher Fight | length13 = 3:45 | title14 = Camelot | length14 = 3:49 | title15 = The Quest | length15 = 2:35 | title16 = Seeing Your Boy Become A Man | length16 = 3:14 | title17 = Laaa Love | length17 = 1:53 | title18 = A Farewell Kiss | length18 = 2:40 | title19 = Teddy's Goodbye | length19 = 3:02 }} ==Release== The film [[Film premiere|premiered]] at the [[Ziegfeld Theatre (1969)|Ziegfeld Theatre]] in New York City on December 11, 2014.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/scene/news/robin-williams-ben-stiller-night-at-the-museum-premiere-1201378034/|title=Ben Stiller, 'Night at the Museum' Cast Remember Robin Williams – Variety|work=Variety|accessdate=December 13, 2014}} It was then released on December 19, 2014 in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://screenrant.com/night-at-museum-3-trailer2/|title='Night at the Museum 3′ Trailer #2: Don't Let the Magic Die|author=Kofi Outlaw|work=Screen Rant|accessdate=December 13, 2014}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb'' grossed $113.7 million in North America, and $249.5 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $363.2 million against a budget of $127 million. In North America, early analysts were predicting a potential $25–$28 million opening.{{cite web | url = https://variety.com/2014/film/news/box-office-the-hobbit-finale-opens-strong-with-24-5-million-1201382550/ | title = Box Office: ‘The Hobbit’ Finale Opens Strong with $24.5 Million | author = Dave McNary | journal=Variety | date = December 18, 2014 | accessdate = December 19, 2014}}{{cite web | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3980&p=.htm | title = Forecast (cont.): 'Night at the Museum,' 'Annie' Open Ahead of Christmas Holiday | author = Ray Subers | website= Box Office Mojo | date = December 17, 2014 | accessdate = December 19, 2014}} In North America, the film was released on December 19, 2014 across 3,785 theaters.{{cite web | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/widest.htm?page=WIDEST&p=.htm | title = Widest Releases | website= Box Office Mojo | accessdate = December 19, 2014}} It opened Friday, December 19, 2014 and earned $5.6 million on its opening day, placing at number three at the box office.{{cite web|url = http://deadline.com/2014/12/weekend-box-office-the-hobbit-the-battle-of-the-five-armies-no-1-annie-night-at-the-museum-1201331370/|title=Hobbit' Wakes Up Auds; 'Annie' Arm Wrestling Ben Stiller For No. 2 – Friday B.O.|author=Anthony D'Alessandro|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=December 20, 2014|accessdate=December 20, 2014}} The film underperformed expectations during its opening weekend, earning $17.1 million, which was relatively lower than the openings of the original film ($30.4 million) and its sequel ($54.1 million).{{cite web |url = https://variety.com/2014/film/news/box-office-the-hobbit-rules-them-all-with-90-6-million-1201384709/|title = Box Office: ‘The Hobbit’ Rules Them All With $90.6 Million|author = Brent Lang|journal = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date = December 21, 2014|accessdate = December 22, 2014}} The film debuted at number two at the box office behind ''[[The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3984&p=.htm| title = Weekend Report (cont.): Final 'Night at the Museum' Narrowly Tops 'Annie'|author=Ray Subers|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|date=December 21, 2014|accessdate=December 29, 2014}} According to 20th Century Fox, the movie's audience was 51% male, with 54% of the audience under the age of 25. In [[CinemaScore]] polls conducted during the opening weekend, cinema audiences gave the film an average grade of "B+", on an A+ to F scale. The film began its international rollout the same weekend as the North American premiere and earned $10.4 million from 27 markets in its opening weekend, debuting at #3 behind at the box office behind ''The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies'' and ''[[Penguins of Madagascar]]''.{{cite web | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3983&p=.htm | title = Around-the-World Roundup: 'Hobbit' Finale Adds $109 Million Overseas | author = Ray Subers | website= Box Office Mojo | date = December 21, 2014 | accessdate = December 29, 2014}}[[Deadline Hollywood]] reported slightly different opening figures: $10.93 million from 29 international markets.{{cite web | url = http://deadline.com/2014/12/international-box-office-hobbit-five-armies-big-hero-6-pk-gone-with-the-bullets-results-1201332492/ | title = 'Hobbit' Rules While Chinese, Indian And French Films Make Noise: Intl BO Update | author = Nancy Tartaglione | website= Deadline.com | date = December 22, 2014 | accessdate = December 29, 2014}}{{cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2014/12/21/box-office-hobbit-battle-of-the-five-armies-soars-to-355m-worldwide/ | title = Box Office: 'Hobbit' Finale Soars To $355M Worldwide | author = Scott Mendelson | journal = ''[[Forbes]]'' | date = December 21, 2014 | accessdate = December 22, 2014}} The film expanded to an additional 40 markets in its second week and grossed $31.2 million. It topped the box office outside North America in its fourth weekend with a total gross of $46.2 million, primarily because of China, where it opened at #1 with $26 million.{{cite web | url = http://deadline.com/2015/01/international-box-office-night-at-the-museum-tomb-taken-3-american-sniper-unbroken-1201347113/ | title = Strong Weekend For Fox, Clint Eastwood at International Box Office | author = Nancy Tartaglione | website= Deadline.com | date = January 11, 2015 | accessdate = January 12, 2015}} The other highest opening figures were from Mexico ($5.85 million), Brazil ($3.1 million), Malaysia ($3.07 million), the UK ($3 million), Australia ($2.8 million), Germany ($2.1 million) and Singapore ($2 million).{{cite web | url = https://deadline.com/2014/12/international-box-office-hobbit-battle-five-armies-exodus-pk-into-the-woods-unbroken-water-diviner-annie-results-1201337477/ | title = 'Hobbit', 'Exodus' Lead XMas Frame; Euro, Korea Pics Boom Locally: Intl BO Update | author = Nancy Tartaglione | website= Deadline.com| date = December 29, 2014 | accessdate = December 29, 2014}}{{cite web | url = https://deadline.com/2015/01/international-box-office-hobbit-taken-3-american-sniper-pk-angel-of-death-1201340651/ | title = 'Hobbit' Passes $500M; 'American Sniper', 'Taken 3′ Skillful: Intl Box Office Update | author = Nancy Tartaglione | website= Deadline.com | date = January 4, 2015 | accessdate = January 5, 2015}} For the weekend of January 16, 2015, the film grossed $17.8 million, which includes a $3.9 million debut in South Korea.{{cite web | url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=4005&p=.htm | title=Around-the-World Roundup: 'Taken' Repeats, 'Hobbit' Hits $800 Million | publisher=IMDB | website=boxofficemojo.com | accessdate=January 22, 2015}} ===Critical response=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film received a 48% approval rating, based on 104 reviews, with an average score of 5/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "While not without its moments, ''Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb'' is a less-than-inspired sendoff for the trilogy."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/night_at_the_museum_secret_of_the_tomb/|title=Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=March 25, 2015}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 47 out of 100, based on 33 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/night-at-the-museum-secret-of-the-tomb | title=Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb Reviews | work=[[Metacritic]] | publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate=January 9, 2015}} In [[CinemaScore]] polls conducted during the opening weekend, cinema audiences gave the film an average grade of "B+" on an A+ to F scale. Scott Foundas of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' gave the film a positive review, praising the visual effects and calling the production values "topnotch", and admiring Guillermo Navarro's work. He added, "A most enjoyable capper to director Shawn Levy and producer Chris Columbus' cheerfully silly and sneakily smart family-entertainment juggernaut... offers little in the way of secrets of surprises, but should add much holiday cheer to Fox's box-office coffers."{{cite web | url = https://variety.com/2014/film/reviews/film-review-night-at-the-museum-secret-of-the-tomb-1201377828/ | title = Film Review: ‘Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb’ | author = Scott Foundas | journal=Variety | date = December 12, 2014 | accessdate = December 19, 2014}} [[Peter Bradshaw]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' gave the film three stars out of five and said, "The third part in what absolutely no one is calling the ''Night at the Museum'' 'trilogy' turns out to be a good-natured and entertainingly surreal panto fantasy."{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/dec/18/night-at-the-museum-secret-of-the-tomb-review | title = Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb review – surreal panto fantasy | author = Peter Bradshaw | newspaper=The Guardian | date = December 18, 2014 | accessdate = December 19, 2014}} [[Glenn Kenny]] awarded the film 2½ stars out of 4 praising the ''[[Indiana Jones (franchise)|Indiana Jones]]'' themed-set while criticizing the performances of the cast and said, "As talent-packed as any ''Night at the Museum'' picture may be—in this third installment... —one doesn't come to a movie of this sort expecting anybody's best work. Or at least one certainly shouldn't, because it won't materialize."{{cite web | url = http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/night-at-the-museum-secret-of-the-tomb-2014 | title = Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb Review | author = Glenn Kenny | website= Rogererbert.com | date = December 18, 2014 | accessdate = December 19, 2014}} Stephanie Zacharek of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' gave the film a positive review, saying "The third installment, ''Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb'' may be the best, and even the generally wound-too-tight Ben Stiller – once again playing a bemused Museum of Natural History guard – is easy to tolerate."{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2014-12-17/film/night-at-the-museum-movies-are-better-than-critics-say-and-this-third-installment-might-be-the-best-of-them/|title=The Night at the Museum Movies Are Better Than Critics Say|author=Stephanie Zacharek|date=December 16, 2014|work=The Village Voice|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Claudia Puig of ''[[USA Today]]'' gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "Where the previous films felt frenetic and forced, this outing feels breezier, more enjoyable and less contrived."{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2014/12/17/night-at-the-museum-secret-of-the-tomb-review/19156899/|title=Third 'Night at the Museum' is breezy, bittersweet fun|author=Claudia Puig|date=December 17, 2014|work=USA Today|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Joe Neumaier of the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, saying "There's a serenity to museum visits, especially if it's a place you know and love. ''Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb'', amazingly, recaptures that feeling in big-studio franchise form."{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/movies/night-museum-secret-tomb-movie-review-article-1.2049288|title='Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb,’ movie review|work=NY Daily News|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Bill Goodykoontz of ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'' gave the film two out of five stars, saying "''Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb'' is a rather lackluster affair, a cash grab that tries to aim a little higher but confuses sappy shortcuts with real emotion."{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/movies/2014/12/17/review-night-museum-secret-waste-talent/20554879/|title=Review: 'Night at the Museum: Tomb' doomed by ennui|date=December 17, 2014|work=The Arizona Republic|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Joe McGovern of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the film a B, saying "It's kind of fun, unembarrassingly, and not least of all because the people who made it look like they had a good time doing so."{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20884491,00.html|title=Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb Review |work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Tom Long of ''[[The Detroit News]]'' gave the film a B, saying "There are some key elements that make this ''Night at the Museum'' sequel work better than its predecessor."{{cite web|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/entertainment/movies/2014/12/19/night-museum-family-friendly-fun/20625777/|title='Night at the Museum' is family-friendly fun|author=Tom Long |newspaper=The Detroit News|date=December 19, 2014|publisher=|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Stephen Whitty of the ''[[Newark Star-Ledger]]'' gave the film two out of four stars, saying "The exhibits in this ''Night at the Museum'' may still come to life nightly. But their latest movie stays stubbornly inert."{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/12/night_at_the_museum_the_secret_of_the_tomb_review_bury_it.html|title='Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb' review: Bury it|work=Newark Star-Ledger|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Tom Russo of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "Seeing Ben Stiller, the late Robin Williams, and their magically roused gang together again, this time in London, is initially all about indulgent, nostalgic smiles rather than new wows. But then comes the movie's exceptionally clever and fresh final act, which delivers genuine surprise along with many laughs."{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/movies/2014/12/18/night-museum-sequel-shakes-off-dust/UBtIYA8016Jz0OAvShvAhJ/story.html|title='Night at the Museum' sequel shakes off the dust|author=Tom Russo|date=December 17, 2014|work=The Boston Globe|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Robbie Collin of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, saying "The third ''Night at the Museum'' film starts strongly, with its heart in the past... It's an exciting opening, and perhaps too exciting for the film's own good. It's hard not to be disappointed when the plot moves back to the present and settles into the time-honoured formula of digitised creatures running riot and famous people in fancy dress doing shtick."{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/filmreviews/11301137/Night-at-the-Museum-Secret-of-the-Tomb-review-so-much-fun.html|title=Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb, review: 'so much fun'|author=Robbie Collin|date=December 18, 2014|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Michael Rechtshaffen of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' gave the film a negative review, saying "Despite relocating across the pond to the esteemed British Museum, the creaky ''Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb'' fails to capitalize on the comic potential provided by that change of venue."{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/night-at-museum-3/review/756594|title='Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb': Film Review|author=Michael Rechtshaffen|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Ignatiy Vishnevetsky of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the film a C+, saying "''Secret of the Tomb'' plays it as a source of corny jokes, pop-culture references, and father-son bonding moments. In other words, it's exactly the kind of film that shouldn't be expected to engage with its assorted bizarre subtexts – but what a movie it could be if it did."{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/creepy-night-museum-series-comes-close-secret-tomb-212990|title=Review: The creepy Night At The Museum series comes to a close with Secret Of The Tomb |work=The A.V. Club|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Sara Stewart of the ''[[New York Post]]'' gave the film two out of four stars, saying "For piquing kids' interest in history and nature, you could do worse than this goofy Ben Stiller franchise. But its third installment is more meh than manic, too reliant on wide shots of the ragtag Museum of Natural History cohorts striding down corridors. You get the feeling returning director Shawn Levy is ready to hang it up."{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2014/12/17/new-night-at-the-museum-is-a-bit-musty/|title=New 'Night at the Museum' is a bit musty|work=New York Post|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} [[Richard Roeper]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' gave the film one and a half stars out of five, saying "The dialogue is schmaltzy and often painfully unfunny. The special effects are often so 1980s-bad, one wonders if it was a deliberate choice, to make the creepy visuals of sculptures dancing and paintings moving less frightening to young viewers. Time and again, terrific actors sink in the equivalent of cinematic quicksand, helpless against the sucking sound of this movie."{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.suntimes.com/movies/night-museum-secret-tomb-please-touch/|title='Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb': Please do not touch|work=Chicago Sun-Times|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} Drew Hunt of [[Slant Magazine]] gave the film one out of four stars, saying "None of the entries in the ''Night at the Museum'' series could ever pass for high art, but a wealth of comedic talent gave the first two installments a madcap energy that somewhat forgave their childish premises. ''Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb'', the third and supposedly final edition in the franchise, is nothing more than an uncomfortably transparent contractual obligation."{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/review/night-at-the-museum-secret-of-the-tomb|title=Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb – Film Review |author=Drew Hunt|date=December 15, 2014|work=Slant Magazine|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} ===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! scope="col"| Award ! scope="col"| Category ! scope="col"| Recipient(s) ! scope="col"| Result ! scope="col"| Ref(s) |- | rowspan="2"| [[2015 Teen Choice Awards|Teen Choice Awards]] | colspan="2"| [[Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie – Comedy|Choice Movie: Comedy]] | {{nom}} | rowspan="2"|{{cite web|url=http://www.teenchoice.com/article/winners-of-%E2%80%9Cteen-choice-2015%E2%80%9D-announced|title=WINNERS OF TEEN CHOICE 2015 ANNOUNCED|work=[[Teen Choice Awards]]|publisher=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]|date=August 16, 2015|accessdate=August 17, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150818075858/http://www.teenchoice.com/article/winners-of-%E2%80%9Cteen-choice-2015%E2%80%9D-announced|archivedate=August 18, 2015|df=mdy-all}} |- | [[Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie Actor – Comedy|Choice Movie Actor: Comedy]] | [[Ben Stiller]] | {{nom}} |- | [[2015 Kids' Choice Awards|Kids' Choice Awards]] | Favorite Movie Actor | Ben Stiller | {{won}} |{{cite news|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2015/02/20/nickelodeon-announces-nominations-for-the-28th-annual-kids-choice-awards/365877/|title=Nickelodeon Announces Nominations for the '28th Annual Kids' Choice Awards'|date=February 20, 2015|website=[[Zap2it]]|accessdate=February 21, 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/02/20/kids-choice-awards-release-nominations-meryl-streep-earns-her-very-first|title=Meryl Streep gets her first Kids' Choice Awards nomination: See the full list|date=February 20, 2015|journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=February 21, 2015}} |- |} ==Home media== ''Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb'' was released on Blu-ray and DVD on March 10, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/Night-at-the-Museum-Secret-of-the-Tomb-Blu-ray/121319/|title=Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb Blu-ray|work=Blu-ray.com|accessdate=January 30, 2015}} The film debuted in second place on the home media charts behind ''[[The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1]]''.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/the-hunger-games-fends-off-night-at-the-museum-on-home-video-sales-charts-1201455823/|title='The Hunger Games' Fends Off 'Night at the Museum' on Home Video Sales Charts|journal=Variety|accessdate=August 6, 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|2692250|Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb}} * {{tcmdb title|2014701|Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb}} * {{mojo title|nightatthemuseum3|Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb}} {{Night at the Museum}} {{Shawn Levy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Night At The Museum: Secret of the Tomb}} [[Category:2014 films]] [[Category:2010s adventure films]] [[Category:2010s comedy films]] [[Category:2010s fantasy films]] [[Category:1492 Pictures films]] [[Category:21 revision.text:
{{Infobox software | name = PC Globe | screenshot = [[File:PC Globe main window.png|PC Globe 3.0|250px]] | caption = PC Globe 3.0 (emulated in [[Dosbox]] on [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]]) | developer = [[PC Globe, inc.]], [[Brøderbund]] | released = 1989 | discontinued = 1994 | operating system = [[MS-DOS]], [[Windows 3.X]], [[Macintosh]] | genre = Educational | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]] }}
'''PC Globe''' is an [[atlas]] for [[MS-DOS]]<ref name="danielsays">{{cite web|url=http://www.danielsays.com/ss-gallery-dos-pc-globe-40.html|title=ss-gallery-dos-pc-globe-40|publisher=danielsays.com|accessdate=2015-02-26}}</ref> and [[Microsoft Windows]], first released in 1989.
It offered information on 190 countries and dependencies.<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=InfoWorld|publisher=InfoWorld Media Group, Inc.|issn=0199-6649|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tDwEAAAAMBAJ|accessdate=2015-02-26}}</ref>
Distributed on [[floppy disk]], the [[Computer program|program]] is divided into several menus that allows one to access the data.
The [[database]] includes a geographic [[map]] of the world, with the possibility to select the country of interest.
For each state there are maps and information (for example, the policy framework, the demographic situation as well as tourist information).
The minimum system requirements of the initial DOS version of the software is a [[8086 processor]], 640 KB of [[RAM]] and a graphics card [[Color Graphics Adapter|CGA]], [[Enhanced Graphics Adapter|EGA]] or [[VGA]].
==Release History== For DOS, '''PC Globe 3.0''' was released in 1989,<ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=PC Mag|publisher=Ziff Davis, Inc.|issn=0888-8507|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5CmkZ3THZtwC|accessdate=2015-02-26}}</ref> with '''PC Globe 4.0''' coming the next year.<ref name="google3">{{cite book|title=PC Mag|publisher=Ziff Davis, Inc.|issn=0888-8507|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u2cfcECC1dwC|accessdate=2015-02-26}}</ref> Still in 1990, an Atari ST version was available.<ref name="emuparadise">{{cite web|url=http://www.emuparadise.me/Atari_ST_ROMs/Pc_Globe_v3.0_%281990%29%28Nathan%29%28fr%29%28Disk_1_of_3%29/119278|title=Pc Globe v3.0 (1990)(Nathan)(fr)(Disk 1 of 3) ROM < Atari ST ROMs | Emuparadise|publisher=emuparadise.me|accessdate=2015-02-26}}</ref>
In 1993 '''PC Globe 5.0''' came out.<ref name="vetusware">{{cite web|url=http://vetusware.com/download/PC%20Globe%205.07%20ES/?id=3756|title=Download PC Globe 5.07 by | VETUSWARE.COM - the biggest free abandonware collection in the universe|publisher=vetusware.com|accessdate=2015-02-26}}</ref>
The latest version is '''PC Globe Maps-N-Facts''' (for PC and Mac) released in 1994.<ref name="archive">{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/1994_Broderbund_PC_Globe_Maps-N-Facts_PC_and_Mac_MNFWIN|title=1994 Broderbund PC Globe Maps-N-Facts (PC and Mac) MNFWIN.iso : Free Download & Streaming : Internet Archive|publisher=archive.org|accessdate=2015-02-26}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Atlases]] [[Category:DOS software]]

revision.text:
{{Technical|date=August 2017}}
'''Qualitative economics''' is the representation and analysis of information about the direction of change (+, -, or 0) in some economic variable(s) as related to change of some other economic variable(s). For the non-zero case, what makes the change ''qualitative'' is that its direction but not its magnitude is specified.<ref name="Quirk1987">James Quirk, 1987. "qualitative economics," ''The [[New Palgrave: A Dictionary of Economics]]'', v. 4, p. 1.</ref>
Typical exercises of qualitative economics include [[Comparative statics|comparative-static]] changes studied in [[microeconomics]] or [[macroeconomics]] and comparative equilibrium-growth states in a [[Exogenous growth model|macroeconomic growth model]]. A simple example illustrating qualitative change is from macroeconomics. Let: :''GDP'' = nominal [[gross domestic product]], a measure of [[national income]] : ''M'' = [[money supply#Scope|money supply]] :''T'' = [[Macroeconomic policy instruments#Fiscal policy|total taxes]]. [[quantity theory of money|Monetary theory]] hypothesizes a positive relationship between ''GDP'' the [[dependent variable]] and ''M'' the [[independent variable]]. Equivalent ways to represent such a '''qualitative relationship''' between them are as a signed functional relationship and as a signed [[derivative]]:
: <math> GDP = f(\overset{+}{M}) \quad\! </math> or <math>\quad\frac{ df(M) }{ dM} > 0.</math> where the '+' indexes a positive relationship of ''GDP'' to ''M'', that is, as ''M'' increases, ''GDP'' increases as a result.
Another [[Model (economics)|model]] of GDP hypothesizes that ''GDP'' has a negative relationship to ''T''. This can be represented similarly to the above, with a theoretically appropriate sign change as indicated:
: <math> GDP = f(\overset{-}{T}) \quad\! </math> or <math>\quad\frac{ df(T)}{ dT} < 0.</math> That is, as ''T'' increases, ''GDP'' decreases as a result. A combined model uses both ''M'' and ''T'' as independent variables. The hypothesized relationships can be equivalently represented as signed functional relationships and signed [[partial derivative]]s (suitable for more than one independent variable):
:<math> GDP = f(\overset{+}{M},\overset{-}{ T}) \,\! \quad </math> or <math>\quad\frac{\partial f(M, T)}{\partial M} > 0,\quad </math> <math>\frac{\partial f(M, T)}{\partial T} < 0.</math>
Qualitative hypotheses occur in earliest history of formal economics but only as to formal economic models from the late 1930s with Hicks's model of [[general equilibrium]] in a competitive economy.<ref>[[J. R. Hicks]], 1939. ''[[Value and Capital]]''. Oxford.</ref> A classic exposition of qualitative economics is Samuelson, 1947.<ref>[[Paul A. Samuelson]], 1947. ''[[Foundations of Economic Analysis]]'', pp. 5, 21-29.</ref> There Samuelson identifies qualitative restrictions and the hypotheses of [[Maxima and minima|maximization]] and stability of [[Economic equilibrium|equilibrium]] as the three fundamental sources of ''meaningful'' theorems — hypotheses about empirical data that could conceivably be refuted by empirical data.<ref name="Quirk1987"/>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * [[J. R. Hicks]], 1939. ''[[Value and Capital]]''. Oxford. * [[Kelvin Lancaster]], 1962. "The Scope of Qualitative Economics," ''Review of Economic Studies'', 29(2), p[https://www.jstor.org/pss/2295817 p. 99]-123. **W.M. Gorman, 1964. "More Scope for Qualitative Economics," ''Review of Economic Studies'', 31(1) p[https://www.jstor.org/pss/2295936 p. 65]-68. * James Quirk, 1987. "qualitative economics," ''The [[New Palgrave: A Dictionary of Economics]]'', v. 4, pp. 1-3. * _____ and Richard Ruppert, 1965. "Qualitative Economics and the Stability of Equilibrium," ''Review of Economic Studies'', 32(4), p[https://www.jstor.org/pss/2295838 p. 311]-326. * [[Paul A. Samuelson]], 1947. ''[[Foundations of Economic Analysis]]'', Harvard University Press. {{ISBN|0-674-31301-1}}
[[Category:Comparative statics]] [[Category:Mathematical and quantitative methods (economics)]]
