revision.text:
'''Comic books''' have been '''recalled''' for various reasons including simple printing errors, stories or images that were deemed inappropriate or to avoid potential lawsuits. The rarest of these books is probably ''[[The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen]]'' volume 1, issue 5, which was recalled due to the inclusion of a 19th-century advertisement for "Marvel"-brand [[douche]]; since ''League'' was published by an imprint of [[DC Comics]], DC's publisher felt that this could be perceived as an attack on DC's main rival, [[Marvel Comics]]. Other notable recalls were the ''[[Elseworlds 80-Page Giant]]'' which included a portrayal of baby [[Superman]] in a microwave, and [[Marvel Knights]]' ''[[Elektra (comics)|Elektra]]'' #3 which included tame nude images of the title character. As well as comics with evidence of a genuine recall, there have been a number of rumored recalls and comics where the publisher (or distributor) has allowed the comic to be returned but has not issued a recall notice. Comic books have been categorized below as verified or unverified/returnable with supporting references. [[File:All Star Batman & Robin 10 Recalled.JPG|thumb|''All Star Batman & Robin'' 10 recalled edition]] ==Verified recalls== This section lists comics verified by the [[Comics Guaranty LLC|CGC]] Collectors Society as being recalled and listed in the "Recalled Editions" competitive comic book set.{{cite web | url=http://comics.www.collectors-society.com/registry/comics/SetScoreDetail.aspx?SetTypeID=354|title=Recalled Editions |accessdate=2010-02-13 |work=CGC Registry |publisher=[[Comics Guaranty LLC|CGC]]|date=2006-03-22 }} ===''Action Comics'' #869=== November 2008, [[DC Comics]]' ''[[Action Comics]]'' #869, the penultimate issue of the "[[Brainiac (story arc)|Brainiac]]" story arc, was recalled by [[DC Comics]] for cover content. The original cover depicted [[Superman]], in civilian attire with his 'S' shield clearly visible, and his adoptive father outside the Kent farmhouse drinking what appears to be beer. [[DC Comics|DC]] issued a statement to retailers that the issue was recalled, and that any copies featuring the original cover be destroyed. The next week, DC reprinted the issue featuring a cover in which the label on the bottle was changed to read, "[[soft drink|soda pop]]". ===''All Star Batman and Robin, the Boy Wonder'' #10=== August 2008, DC Comics
''All Star Batman and Robin, the Boy Wonder'' was a mature-readers comic in which street thugs used profanity. However, DC did not want this language to actually appear in the book, so the text was placed in the speech bubbles and then blacked-out.{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=17985 |title=Wash Your Mouth with Batsoap|work=Lying in the Gutters |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |date=2008-09-09 }} However, in issue #10, slightly different shades of ink were used in the two elements leaving the vulgar words just readable. [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]] was quoted as saying "This is the first I've heard of it," he said. "I have no idea how this awful thing happened. It's just one of those terrible and glorious things that happen time to time in publishing", "...And my first reaction is simple: I want at least three copies."{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/herocomplex/2008/09/batman-and-robi.html |title='Batman and Robin' drops F-bomb|publisher=Hero Complex |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2008-09-11 }} ===''Elektra'' volume 2, #3=== November 2001, [[Marvel Comics]]
[[Elektra (comics)|Elektra]] appears nude in shadow.{{cite web |url=http://www.cgccomics.com/gallery/details.aspx?comic=1294 |title=CGC record: Elektra #v2 #3 |accessdate=2008-09-13 |work=CGC information and population|publisher=[[Comics Guaranty LLC]] |date=2008-09-13 }} ===''Elseworlds 80-Page Giant''=== August 1999, DC Comics
In [[Kyle Baker]] and [[Liz Glass]]' story, [[Elseworlds 80-Page Giant|"Letitia Lerner, Superman's Babysitter"]], the super-toddler climbs into a microwave. When [[Paul Levitz]], the president of [[DC Comics]], objected to this portrayal of the infant [[Clark Kent]], most copies were recalled and pulped. The offending story won an Eisner Award and was subsequently reprinted in DC's ''Bizarro Comics'' collection. In 2011, the entire issue was reprinted under the title ''DC Comics Presents: Elseworlds 80-Page Giant #1.'' It went on sale December 28, 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.dccomics.com/comics/dc-comics-presents-elseworlds-80-page-giant-2011/dc-comics-presents-elseworlds-80-page-giant | title= DC COMICS PRESENTS: ELSEWORLDS 80-PAGE GIANT #1 }} ===''Halle the Hooters Girl'' #1=== January 1998, Cabbage Comics
The San Antonio Texas (Gold Foil) Edition was specially produced (only 2000 made) for the National Tour of the swimsuit/calendar models who were the inspiration. However, a lawsuit ensued with the [[Hooters]] organization which led to the comic being recalled. The standard recalled edition is thought to be the rarer of the two versions although the set scores in the [[Comics Guaranty LLC|CGC]] registry seem to contradict this.{{cite web |url=http://comics.www.collectors-society.com/registry/comics/SlotScoreDetail.aspx?SlotID=41838| title=Recalled Editions: Halle the Hooters Girl 1|accessdate=2010-02-13| work=[[Comics Guaranty LLC|CGC]]| date=2010-02-13}}{{cite web |url=http://comics.www.collectors-society.com/registry/comics/SlotScoreDetail.aspx?SlotID=41839 | title= Recalled Editions: Halle the Hooters Girl 1 Gold Foil Edition|accessdate=2010-02-13| work=CGC Registry|date=2010-02-13}} ===''The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen'' Volume 1, #5=== Issue #5 of Volume One contained an authentic advertisement for a Marvel-brand [[douche]] from the early part of the 20th century. This ad caused [[DC Comics]] executive [[Paul Levitz]] to order the entire print run destroyed over concerns that this could lead to litigation with their main rival [[Marvel Comics]]. None of the recalled comics were ever distributed in the US; however, a small batch had been shipped to the UK and escaped the destruction. With only 100 thought to exist this makes it more than 10-20 times rarer than the ''[[Elseworlds 80-Page Giant]]'' that Paul Levitz also recalled, and is probably the rarest modern comic book in existence.{{cite web | url=http://www.recalledcomics.com/LeagueOfExtraOrdinaryGentlemen5RecalledMarvelAd.php | title=''League Of Extraordinary Gentlemen #5 Recalled'' | work=Recalled Comics.com | accessdate=2011-01-26}} In ''[[Top 10 (comics)|Top 10]]'', [[Alan Moore|Moore]] creates a "[[Miracleman|Miracle]] Douche Recall" headline on a newspaper.{{issue|date=September 2013}} ===''The Matrix: Comic Book Preview''=== March 1999, [[Warner Bros.]]
This comic was specially printed for the cinema audience for [[The Matrix|the film of the same title]]. However, the content was deemed too mature for cinema audience and it was withdrawn and pulped. This comic, although recalled, retains a low value.{{cite web| url=http://www.comicspriceguide.com/p-issues.asp?t_ID=17654| title=MATRIX (1999)| accessdate=2010-02-13| work=ComicsBookPriceGuide.com| publisher=CPG| date=2010-02-13}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===''Millennium Edition: Mad'' #1=== February 2000, DC Comics
[[Millennium Edition (DC Comics)|This comic]] was a reprint of the original first issue of ''[[Mad (magazine)|Mad]]'', however, inside [[DC Comics]] used their own [[masthead (publishing)|masthead]] and copyright instead of [[EC Publications|EC]]'s so it was withdrawn to be corrected.{{cite web |url= http://comics.www.collectors-society.com/registry/comics/awards/WinningComicDetail.aspx?AwardSetComicID=967753&AwardSetID=34772 |title= Nude Microwave Scandal: Millennium Edition: Mad 1 |accessdate=2012-11-02}} A very low number of these comic books have been encapsulated by [[Comics Guaranty LLC|CGC]].{{cite web |url=http://comics.www.collectors-society.com/registry/comics/SlotScoreDetail.aspx?SlotID=41839 | title= Millennium Edition: Mad |accessdate=2010-02-13| work=CGC Census|publisher=[[Comics Guaranty LLC|CGC]]| date=2010-02-13}} ===''Phonogram: The Singles Club'' #5=== October 2009, [[Image Comics]]
Recalled and pulped due to a printing error that caused the bar-code from issue #4 to be used.{{cite web|url= http://www.comicspriceguide.com/p-issues.asp?t_ID=45372|title= PHONOGRAM: THE SINGLES CLUB (2008-2009)|accessdate= 2010-02-13|work= ComicsBookPriceGuide.com|publisher= CPG|date= 2010-02-13}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===''Star Wars: Return of the Jedi''=== May 1983, Marvel Comics
As reported in ''[[Comics Buyer's Guide]]'' #497 (May 27, 1983), actor and comic book fan [[Mark Hamill]] discovered copies of Marvel Comics' comic book adaptation of the ''[[Return of the Jedi]]'' film, on sale a month prior to the release of the film, and alerted [[Lucasfilm]]. According to Marvel's [[direct market|Direct Sales]] Manager [[Carol Kalish]], Marvel swiftly recalled the book off the stands upon learning this, though it did not prevent premature revelation of many of the film's secrets.[http://cbgxtra.com/uncategorized/cbg-1216-97-a-look-back-at-marvels-star-wars-comics "The Jedi returns but just a bit too soon!"] ''[[Comics Buyer's Guide]]'' #1216 (March 7, 1997) ===''Tangled Web, the Thousand Spider-Man'' #1=== June 2001, Marvel Comics
The first issue of the comic was produced on the wrong paper stock giving it a matte finish. The comic was withdrawn and the cover reprinted on the correct stock.{{cite web|url= http://www.comicspriceguide.com/p-issues.asp?t_ID=5193|title= SPIDER-MAN'S TANGLED WEB (2001-2003)|accessdate= 2010-02-13|work= ComicsBookPriceGuide.com|publisher= CPG|date= 2010-02-13}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===''Universe X Spidey'' #1=== January 2001, Marvel Comics
This alternate-universe [[Spider-Man]] book was recalled after it was discovered that artist [[Al Milgrom]] had hidden slanderous comments about former Marvel Comics editor [[Bob Harras]] within the issue. On page 28, panel 3, the spines of books on a bookshelf in the background read, "Harras, ha ha, he's gone, good riddance to bad rubbish he was a, Nasty (blurred), s.o.b.". when the comic is turned sideways. The comic was distributed to retailers as part of the First Look scheme, in which retailers get to see a copy of next week’s issue, but then recalled and pulped when the slander was spotted. [[Al Milgrom|Milgrom]] was fired and then quietly rehired several weeks later.{{dead link|date=August 2012}}[http://forum.newsarama.com/archive/index.php/t-5958.html "Question about Universe X: Spidey variant"]. Newsarama. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090804230519/http://forum.newsarama.com/archive/index.php/t-5958.html |date=August 4, 2009 }} ===''Wolverine'' #131=== November 1998, Marvel Comics
This issue featured a genuine error where, instead of the word "killer", the [[antisemitism|antisemitic]] word "[[kike]]" made it into [[Viper (Madame Hydra)|Viper]]'s description of [[Wolverine (character)|Wolverine]]'s archenemy [[Sabretooth (comics)|Sabretooth]].{{cite web |url=http://www.newsarama.com/comics/090811-ASBR10eBay.html|accessdate=2008-11-09| title =Rocking eBay - All-Star Batman & Robin #10 |work=News - Comics|publisher= www.newsarama.com| date=2010-02-13}} ==Unverified recalls and returnable comics== This section lists comics that have been rumored as recalls or have been voluntarily returnable to the publisher (i.e. a recall notice was not issued). ===''Action Comics'' #309=== February 1964, DC Comics
In one of the stories in this anthology issue, Superman visits the [[White House]], and trusts President [[John F. Kennedy]] with his secret identity. The story was produced shortly before [[Kennedy assassination|Kennedy was assassinated]], which led to the cancellation of its publication. It was eventually published months later.{{cite news|url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/movies/superman-american-patriot-illegal-immigrant-or-both/|title=Superman: American patriot, illegal immigrant or both?|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=May 15, 2011|author=Anthony, Ted}} ===''Adventures of Superman'' #596=== November 2001, DC Comics
This issue was shipped to stores the day after the [[September 11 attacks]] in [[New York City]]. Due to an unfortunate coincidence the [[Superman]] comic features a scene in which [[Metropolis (comics)|Metropolis]]' twin LexCorp Towers have sustained damage due to events in the "[[Our Worlds at War]]" storyline. DC quickly announced that the issue was returnable although few, if any, were actually returned.{{cite web |url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/714.html |title=DC Makes Adventures of Superman #596 Returnable |publisher=ICv2 |date=2001-09-17 }} ===''Conan and the Demons of Khitai'' #3=== December 2005, [[Dark Horse Comics]]
''[[Conan the Barbarian|Conan]] and the Demons of Khitai'' #3 featured a spoof nude advert for ''Conan'' #24. After complaints, a second printing was issued, replacing the spoof nude advert with actual (non-nude) advert for ''Conan'' #24, with retailers offered the option to swap copies (hence not technically a recall).{{cite web |url= http://www.comicbookdb.com/issue.php?ID=27691 |title= Conan and the Demons of Khitai (2005) - #3 |publisher=The Comic Book Database |date=2006-02-03}} ===''Death: The High Cost of Living'' #3=== May 1993, [[Vertigo (DC Comics)|DC/Vertigo]]
Page 19 and 20 in the first print were not facing each other, which led to this being corrected and reprinted.{{cite web |url= http://www.neilgaimanbibliography.com/comics/highcostofliving/deaththcol-3corrected.html |title= Death: The High Cost Of Living #3 |publisher=neilgaimanbibliography |date=2005-08-22 }} ===''Doctor Strange, Sorcerer Supreme'' #15=== March 1990, Marvel Comics
[[Jackson Guice]]'s cover for ''Doctor Strange'' #15 (March 1990) used [[Christian music]] singer [[Amy Grant]]'s likeness without her permission,{{cite web |url=http://www.comics.org/details.lasso?id=47723 |title=Doctor Strange, Sorcerer Supreme #15 |publisher=The Grand Comics Database Project }} leading to her management filing a complaint against Marvel Comics, saying the cover gave the appearance she was associating with witchcraft. A US District Court sealed an out-of-court settlement between Grant and Marvel in early 1991, with a consent decree that Marvel did not admit to any liability or wrongdoing.Cronin, Brian [http://goodcomics.comicbookresources.com/2008/02/28/comic-book-urban-legends-revealed-144/ "Comic Book Urban Legends Revealed #144] Comic Book Resources February 29, 2008 Retrieved December 2, 2010{{Cite news|title=Amy Grant Sues Marvel|publisher=[[The Comics Journal]]|work=No. 136|date=July 1990}}{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=CSTB&p_theme=cstb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB372DBA6203D26&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Plus Entertainment|accessdate=December 6, 2007|publisher=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|author=Chicago Sun-Times |work=archived - Excerpt available | date=April 9, 1990}} ===''Ka-Zar The Savage'' #12=== March 1982, Marvel Comics
Most copies have a blank panel on the bottom left of page 10. About 1600 copies (of 80000 issues printed) show a red ink drawing of Dante in that panel.[http://www.comics.org/issue/36195/ ''Ka-Zar the Savage'' #12 (March 1982] at the Grand Comics Database In the "[[Bullpen Bulletins]]" page in Marvel Comics cover-dated June 1982, Editor-in-Chief [[Jim Shooter]] humorously explains this with "The First Annual Shooter Awards". Shooter wrote "The Award for Worst Engraver's Error goes to Chemical Color for ''Ka-Zar'' #12 "Belasco...!" in which an entire panel, a color-hold, was dropped out!" ===''Sandman'' #18 ("A Dream of a Thousand Cats")=== August 1990, DC/Vertigo
There are two versions of this issue where the first page has either three panels colored blue or the same three panels colored yellow. The blue panel variant is listed by [[Comics Guaranty LLC|CGC]] as an "error version" and very few are thought to exist.{{cite web |url=http://www.recalledcomics.com/Sandman18ErrorEdition.php |title=The Sandman #18 Blue Variant |publisher=www.recalledcomics.com |date=2010-03-16 }} ===''Sandman'' #19 ("A Midsummer Night's Dream")=== September 1990, DC/Vertigo
Pages 18 and 19 printed in the wrong order (not recalled).{{cite web |url=http://www.neilgaimanbibliography.com/comics/sandman/sandman-19misprint.html |title=The Sandman #19 (Misprint - 18/20) |publisher=neilgaimanbibliography |date=2005-08-22 }} ===''Spider-Man: Reign'' #1=== December 2006, Marvel Comics
On December 6, 2006, the same day that ''[[Spider-Man: Reign]]'' #1 shipped to retailers, [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]] issued an apology and a "CONTENT ADVISORY" statement, announcing that the issue was now returnable as it "contains an image that may be misinterpreted by some readers as inappropriate". This was due to a panel showing a naked and elderly [[Spider-Man|Peter Parker]] sitting on a bed, an image in which his genitalia are apparently visible. ''Spider-Man: Reign'' had shipped with a T+ (Teens & Up) rating. The second printing avoided this problem by modifying the panel, hiding Parker's body in shadow.{{cite web |url= http://sequentiallyspeaking.blogspot.com/2006/12/full-monty.html|title= Comic Book Conversations|publisher=Sequentially speaking |date=2006-12-06 }} ===''Venom: Lethal Protector'' #1=== February 1993, Marvel Comics
Returnable (not recalled) due to “Black Cover” printing error.{{cite web |url=http://www.atomicavenue.com/Atomic/IssueDetail.aspx?ID=250033|title=Venom: Lethal Protector #1 Variation A |publisher=AtomicAvenue |date=2005-08-22 }} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Comic book collecting]] [[Category:Comics terminology]] [[Category:Recalled publications| Comics]]

revision.comment: Fixed box heading 'Mueseum' > 'Museum'
revision.text:
{{Infobox museum | name = Royal Armouries Museum | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = Royal Armouries Logo.svg | logo_upright = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | map_type = | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord}} --> | former_name = | established = 1983 ({{formatnum:{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}} - 1983}}}} years ago) | dissolved = | location = United Kingdom | type = [[Weapon]] & [[Armour]] | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = 75,000 | visitors = | founder = | executive_director = | leader_type = | leader = | director = | president = | ceo = | chairperson = | curator = | architect = | historian = | owner = [[Non-departmental public body]] of | publictransit = | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = {{URL|royalarmouries.org}} | embedded = }} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} [[File:RoyalArmoryLeeds.JPG|thumb|The Hall of Steel in the [[Royal Armouries Museum|Royal Armouries in Leeds]]]] [[File:Leeds-RA-Gothic-Armor-001.jpg|thumb|[[Gothic plate armour]], [[Royal Armouries Museum|Royal Armouries in Leeds]]]] [[File:Fale London 28.jpg|thumb|Part of the display at the [[Tower of London]]]] The '''Royal Armouries''' is the United Kingdom's National Museum of [[Weapons|Arms]] and [[Armour]]. It is the United Kingdom's oldest museum, and one of the oldest museums in the world.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} It is also one of the largest collections of arms and armour in the world, comprising the UK's National Collection of Arms and Armour, National [[Artillery]] Collection, and National [[Firearms]] Collection. Its historic base is in the [[Tower of London]], but today the collection is split across three sites:<ref name="RA">{{cite web |url=http://www.royalarmouries.org/about-us/ |title=Royal Armouries official website - About Us |accessdate=8 October 2009}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Location ! Coordinates |- |[[Royal Armouries Museum]] ([[Leeds]]) |{{coord|53.791866|-1.532258|display=inline|region:GB_scale:2000|name=Royal Armouries Museum}} |- |[[Tower of London]] ([[London]]) |{{coord|51.508545|-0.076310|display=inline|region:GB_scale:2000|name=Tower of London}} |- |[[Fort Nelson, Hampshire|Fort Nelson]] ([[Portsmouth]]) |{{coord|50.860691|-1.138867|display=inline|region:GB_scale:2000|name=Fort Nelson}} |}
From 2004 to 2015, a limited selection of items was also on display in [[Louisville, Kentucky]], in the United States, in cooperation with the [[Frazier History Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/local/2014/10/24/frazier-museum-returns-british-armor/17845601/ |title=Frazier Museum returns British armor <!-- (sic) --> |work=The Courier-Journal |date=24 October 2014 |accessdate=24 January 2017}}</ref>
==History== The Royal Armouries is one of the ancient institutions of the Tower of London and was originally engaged in the manufacture of [[armour]] for the [[Kings of England]]. The Office of the Armoury grew out of the department known as the King's [[Privy Wardrobe]] at the Tower of London in the mid-15th century. Overseen from 1423 by the Master of the King's Armour, and based in the [[White Tower (Tower of London)|White Tower]], the Office was responsible for manufacturing armour and edged weapons for the monarch and his armies; it functioned alongside the [[Office of Ordnance]], which had responsibility for firearms.<ref name="Stewart 96">{{cite book|last1=Stewart|first1=Richard W.|title=The English Ordnance Office 1585–1625|date=1996|publisher=Boydell Press|location=Woodbridge, Suffolk}}</ref>
The Armoury oversaw storehouses and workshops at Woolwich and Portsmouth, and at various royal palaces (most notably the [[Greenwich armour|Greenwich Armoury]], which specialized in richly decorated ceremonial armour). In 1545, it is recorded that a visiting foreign dignitary paid to view the Armoury collection at the Tower of London. By the time of [[Charles II of England|Charles II]], there was a permanent public display there; the "Spanish Armoury" which included instruments of torture and the "Line of Kings"—a row of wooden effigies representing the kings of England. This makes it the first [[museum]] in Britain.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.royalarmouries.org/visit-us/tower-of-london |title=Tower of London |accessdate=29 September 2010}}</ref> [[File:12andahalf inch muzzle loading rifled gun (1875).jpg|thumb|left|[[Fort Nelson, Hampshire|Fort Nelson]], a 12.5 inch muzzle loading rifled gun for a shore battery, 1875]]
The influence of the Armoury began to wane as traditional weapons gave way increasingly to firearms in the field of war. In the 1620s, swords, lances and items of armour were still used in battle, but for the most part were being issued by the Office of Ordnance (which was becoming a sizeable department of State) rather than by the Armoury. The latter, however, remained staffed and operational until 1671, when it was finally absorbed by the Ordnance Board; the board continued to maintain, and indeed expanded, the Armoury as a museum.<ref name="Stewart 96" />
The Tower was engaged in the development, manufacture and storage of a wide variety of weaponry until the Board of Ordnance was abolished in 1855. Thereafter the historic armoury collection remained. Only a small part of this could be displayed, however, and in 1995, much of the [[artillery]] collection was moved to [[Fort Nelson, Hampshire|Fort Nelson]] in [[Hampshire]] and the following year a new [[Royal Armouries Museum]] was opened in Leeds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aim25.ac.uk/cats/70/7244.htm |title=Royal Armouries Library, London: Royal Armouries and Office of Ordnance |accessdate=29 September 2010}}</ref> The remaining part of the collection relates directly to the Tower.
The [[National Heritage Act 1983]] established the Armouries as a [[non-departmental public body]], now sponsored by the [[Department for Culture, Media and Sport]].
==Master of the Armouries==
The head of the Royal Armouries is known as the '''Master of the Armouries'''. This was an ancient office that was revived in 1935 when the Royal Armouries became a national museum.<ref>{{cite web|title=Royal Armouries and Office of Ordnance|url=http://www.aim25.ac.uk/cats/70/7244.htm|website=AIM25|accessdate=18 February 2016|date=September 2003}}</ref> The current Director General and Master of the Armouries is [[Edward Impey]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Director General and Master of the Armouries|url=https://www.royalarmouries.org/about-us/people/director-general|website=Royal Armouries|accessdate=18 February 2016}}</ref>
===Master of the Armoury=== The Master of the Armoury was responsible for maintaining a store of armour and weapons for use in the event of war and had an office in the Tower of London. The first use of the title was in 1462.
* 1462–1485 ?? * Sir [[Richard Guildford]] (1485–1506) (also [[Master of the Ordnance]])<ref name = HL/> * Sir [[Edward Guildford]] (1506–1533)<ref name = HL/> * Sir [[John Dudley, 1st Duke of Northumberland|John Dudley]] (1533–1544)<ref name = HL/> * [[Thomas Darcy, 1st Baron Darcy of Chiche]] (1544–1553) <ref name = HL/> * Sir [[Richard Southwell (courtier)|Richard Southwell]] (1554–1559) (also [[Master of the Ordnance]])<ref name = HL/> * [[Sir George Howard (courtier)|Sir George Howard]] (1560–1580)<ref name = HL/> * [[Henry Lee of Ditchley|Sir Henry Lee]] (1580–1611)<ref name = HL>{{cite book|title=Sir Henry Lee (1533–1611): Elizabethan Courtier|first= Sue|last= Thompson}}</ref> * [[Sir Thomas Monson, 1st Baronet]] (1611–1616) <ref>{{cite book|title=The Ben Jonson Encyclopedia|first=D.Heywood|last= Brock|page= 322}}</ref> * [[William Legge (Royalist)|William Legge]] (1636–1646) * Robert Spaven (1647–?1648) <ref>{{cite book|title=Journals of the House of Lords, Volume 9|page=640}}</ref> * [[Anthony Nicholl]] (1648–?1658)<ref>{{cite book|title=Journals of the House of Lords, Volume 10|page= 470}}</ref> * [[William Legge (Royalist)|William Legge]] (restored to office 1660–1670) * ''Office abolished in 1671''
===Master of the Armouries=== * Charles John Ffoulkes (1935–1938) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aim25.ac.uk/cats/70/7245.htm|title= Royal Armouries Library, London|accessdate= 26 May 2016}}</ref> * [[James Mann (curator)|Sir James Mann]] (1938–1962)<ref>{{cite news|title= Gloucester Citizen|date=6 December 1938}}</ref> * Arthur Richard Dufty (1963–1976)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-a-r-dufty-1502420.html|title= Obituary: A. R. Dufty|publisher= The Independent|accessdate= 26 May 2016}}</ref> * Alexander Vesey Bethune (Nick) Norman (1977–1988) <ref>{{cite book|title=British Basket-hilted Swords: A Typology of Basket-type Sword Hilts|first= Cyril|last= Mazanski|page=dedication}}</ref> * [[Guy Wilson (historian)|Guy Wilson]], 1988–2002<ref>{{cite web|title=WILSON, Guy Murray|url=http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whoswho/U40237|website=Who's Who 2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=18 February 2016|date=November 2015}}</ref> * Paul Evans, July 2003 – September 2008<ref>{{cite news|last1=Small|first1=Jeremy|title=Museum boss quits|url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/3772209.Museum_boss_quits/|accessdate=18 February 2016|work=The York Press|date=20 October 2008}}</ref> * Lieutenant-General [[Jonathon Riley (British Army officer)|Jonathon Riley]], September 2009 – November 2012 * Dr [[Edward Impey]], October 2013 – present
==References== {{commons category}} {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{GeoGroupTemplate}} * {{official website|http://www.royalarmouries.org/|name=Royal Armouries official website}}
{{Department for Culture, Media and Sport}}
[[Category:Armories (military)]] [[Category:Charities based in England]] [[Category:Collections of museums in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Exempt charities]] [[Category:Army museums in London]] [[Category:Museums in the London Borough of Tower Hamlets]] [[Category:Museums sponsored by the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport]] [[Category:Non-departmental public bodies of the United Kingdom government]] [[Category:Tower of London]] [[Category:Armour collections]]

revision.comment: [[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Notes & Records of the Royal Society → Notes and Records of the Royal Society
revision.text:
{{About|the type of museum|institutions named Science Museum|Science Museum (disambiguation)|a list of science museums|List of science museums}} {{more footnotes|date=June 2014}} [[File:Science Museum of Virginia 20070916.jpg|thumb|Entrance to the [[Science Museum of Virginia]] ]]
A '''science museum''' is a [[museum]] devoted primarily to [[science]]. Older science museums tended to concentrate on static displays of objects related to [[natural history]], [[paleontology]], [[geology]], industry and industrial machinery, etc. Modern trends in [[museology]] have broadened the range of subject matter and introduced many interactive exhibits. Many if not most modern science museums{{snd}} which increasingly refer to themselves as '''science centers''' or "discovery centers"{{snd}} also emphasize [[technology]], and are therefore also [[technology museum]]s.
The mission statements of science centers and modern museums vary, but they are united in being places that make science accessible and encourage the excitement of discovery. They are an integral and dynamic part of the learning environment, promoting exploration from the first [[eureka moment|"Eureka!" moment]] to today's cutting-edge research.
{{quote box|bgcolor=#CCDDFF|align=right|width=25% |quote=...The public museum as understood today is a collection of specimens and other objects of interest to the scholar, the man of science as well as the more casual visitor, arranged and displayed in accordance with the scientific method. In its original sense, the term 'museum' meant a spot dedicated to the muses - 'a place where man's mind could attain a mood of aloofness above everyday affairs'.|source=[[Museum of Jurassic Technology]], Introduction & Background, p. 2}}
==History== As early as the Renaissance, many aristocrats collected curiosities for display to their family. Universities and particularly [[medical schools]] also maintained study collections of specimens for their students. Scientists and collectors displayed their finds in private [[Cabinet of curiosities|cabinets of curiosities]]. Such collections were the predecessors of modern [[natural history]] museums.
The first purpose-built museum covering [[natural philosophy]] and open to the public from 1683 was the [[Museum of the History of Science, Oxford|original Ashmolean museum]] (now called the Museum of the History of Science) in [[Oxford, UK|Oxford]], although its scope was mixed.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Fox |first=Robert | date=January 2006 |title=The history of science, medicine and technology at Oxford |journal=[[Notes and Records of the Royal Society]] |volume=60 |issue=1 |pages=69–83 |url= http://rsnr.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/60/1/69.short |doi=10.1098/rsnr.2005.0129}}</ref> The first dedicated science museum was the [[Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales|Museo de Ciencias Naturales]], in [[Madrid]], [[Spain]]. Opened in 1752, it almost disappeared during the [[Francisco Franco|Franco]] regime, but it recovered afterwards and today works closely with the [[Spanish National Research Council|CSIC]].<ref>[http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2007/06/01/ciencia/1180686767.html El Museo de Ciencias Naturales alerta de su 'colapso por falta de espacio' | elmundo.es<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The [[Utrecht University Museum]], among others, still displays an extensive collection of 18th-century animal and human "rarities" in its original setting.
Another line in the genealogy of science museums came during the [[Industrial Revolution]], with great national exhibits intended to showcase the triumphs of both science and industry. For example, the Great Exhibition in [[The Crystal Palace]] (1851) eventually gave rise to [[London Science Museum|London's Science Museum]].
In [[United States|America]], various Natural History Societies established collections in the early 19th century, which evolved into museums. Notable was the early New England Museum of Natural History, (now the [[Museum of Science, Boston|Museum of Science]]) which opened in [[Boston]] in 1864. The Academy of Science of Saint Louis was founded in 1856 as the first scientific organization west of the Mississippi (although the organization managed scientific collections for several decades a formal museum was not created until the mid-20th century).
==Modern science museums== [[File:California Science Center (8089345453).jpg|thumb|Space exhibit at the [[California Science Center]]]] The modern interactive science museum appears to have been pioneered by Munich’s [[Deutsches Museum]] in the early 20th century. This museum had moving exhibits where visitors were encouraged to push buttons and work levers. The concept was taken to the US by [[Julius Rosenwald]], chairman of [[Sears, Roebuck and Company]], who visited the Deutsches Museum with his young son in 1911. He was so-captivated by the experience that he decided to build a similar museum in his home town. Chicago's [[Museum of Science and Industry (Chicago)|Museum of Science and Industry]] opened in phases between 1933 and 1940.
In 1959 the Museum of Science and Natural History (now the [[Saint Louis Science Center]]) was formally created by the Academy of Science of Saint Louis, featuring many interactive science and history exhibits.
In August 1969, [[Frank Oppenheimer]] dedicated his new [[Exploratorium]] in [[San Francisco]] almost completely to interactive science exhibits. The Exploratorium published the details of their own exhibits in "Cookbooks" that served as an inspiration to many other museums around the world.
Opened in September 1969, the [[Ontario Science Centre]] continued the trend of featuring interactive exhibits rather than static displays.
In 1973, the first [[Imax|Omnimax]] theater opened as the [[Reuben H. Fleet Science Center|Reuben H. Fleet Space Theater and Science Center]] in San Diego's Balboa Park. The tilted-dome Space Theater doubled as a [[planetarium]]. The Science Center was an Exploratorium-style museum included as a small part of the complex. This combination interactive science museum, planetarium and Omnimax theater pioneered a configuration that many major science museums follow today.
[[File:Science Museum London 1110466 nevit.jpg|thumb|left|Interactive exhibit at the [[Science Museum London]]]]
Also in 1973, the [[Association of Science-Technology Centers]] (ASTC) was founded as an international organization to provide a collective voice, professional support, and programming opportunities for science centers, museums, and related institutions.
As the flavor of interactivity spread worldwide, the massive [[Cite des Sciences et de l'Industrie]] opened in Paris in 1986, and smaller but no less influential national centers soon followed in Spain, Finland, and Denmark. In the UK, the first interactive centers also opened in 1986 on a modest scale, but their real blossoming more than a decade later was fuelled by Lottery funding for projects to celebrate the millennium.
Since the 1990s, science museums and centers, such as [[Thailand]]'s [[National Science Museum (Thailand)|National Science Museum]], have been created or greatly expanded in East Asia, South Asia, and other parts of the developing word.
[[Image:Hoplostethus atlanticus 01 Pengo.jpg|thumb|Museum specimen of an endangered fish, the [[Orange Roughy]] ]]
However, in many more institutionalized organizations the improvised, experimental nature of the Oppenheimer era has been diluted in favor of a standardized view of science, often dominated by governmental, corporate, and commercial messages.
==Science center== [[File:Cloud chamber as science for general public.jpg|thumb|[[Cloud chamber]]s are very popular among science centers in explanation of [[radioactivity]]. Cloud chambers are able to visualize otherwise [[invisible]] [[particles]] of [[radiation]], thus allowing [[general public]] to grasp theoretical concepts in practice.]] Museums that brand themselves as '''science centers''' emphasize a hands-on approach, featuring interactive exhibits that encourage visitors to experiment and explore.
The first science center was [[Urania (Berlin)|Urania]] founded in [[Berlin]] in 1888 [http://www.ifh.de/CHEP97/museum.htm] [https://web.archive.org/web/20080926175445/http://www.ecsite.net/new/blank.asp?type=projects&keyword=history]. The Academy of Science of Saint Louis (founded in 1856) created the Saint Louis Museum of Science and Natural History in 1959 ([[Saint Louis Science Center]]), but generally science centers are a product of the 1960s and later. In the [[United Kingdom]], many of them were founded as [[Millennium Commission|Millennium projects]], with funding from the [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lotteries Fund]].
The first "science center" in the United States was the [[Science Center of Pinellas]] County, founded in 1959. The [[Pacific Science Center]] (one of the first large organizations to call itself a "science center" rather than a museum) opened in a [[Seattle World's Fair]] building in 1962. The [[Smithsonian Institution]] invited visitors into a new Discovery Room in its [[National Museum of Natural History]] in [[Washington, DC]], where they could touch and handle formerly off-limits specimens.{{when|date=June 2014}} In 1969, [[Frank Oppenheimer|Oppenheimer]]'s [[Exploratorium]] opened in [[San Francisco]], [[California]], and the Ontario Science Centre opened near [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada. By the early 1970s, [[COSI Columbus]], then known as the Center of Science and Industry in [[Columbus, Ohio]], had run its first "camp-in."
It did not take long for these new-style museums to band together for mutual support. In 1971, 16 museum directors gathered to discuss the possibility of starting a new association{{snd}} one more specifically tailored to their needs than the existing American Association of Museums (now the [[American Alliance of Museums]]). The [[Association of Science-Technology Centers]] (ASTC) was formally established in 1973, headquartered in Washington DC, but with an international organizational membership. The corresponding European organization is ECSITE [http://www.ecsite.net] and in the UK the Association of Science and Discovery Centres (ASDC) represent the interests of science engagement organisations [http://www.sciencecentres.org.uk/about/].
In India, the [[National Council of Science Museums]] runs science centers at several places including [[National Science Centre, Delhi|Delhi]], [[Regional Science Centre, Bhopal|Bhopal]], [[Raman Science Centre|Nagpur]] and [[Ranchi Science Centre|Ranchi]]. There are few private Science Centers as well, noted among them are [[Birla Science Museum]] and The Science Garage in Hyderabad.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Science Garage|url=http://sciencegarage.org/|website=sciencegarage.org |publisher=The Science Garage|accessdate=15 February 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of science museums]] * [[Science education]] * [[Science festival]] * [[Science outreach]] * [[Physics Outreach]] * [[List of natural history museums]]
==References== {{reflist}}
* Kaushik, R.,1996, "Effectiveness of Indian science centres as learning environments : a study of educational objectives in the design of museum experiences", Unpublished PhD thesis, University of Leicester, UK * Kaushik, R.,1996, "Non-science-adult-visitors in science centres: what is there for them to do?", ''Museological Review'', Vol. 2, No. 1, p. 72–84. * Kaushik, R.,1996, "Health matters in science museums: a review" in Pearce, S. (ed.) ''New Research in Museum Studies'', Vol. 6, Athlone Press, London/Atlantic Highlands, p. 186–193. * Kaushik, R.,1997, "Attitude development in science museums/centres", in ''Proceedings of the Nova Scotian Institute of Science'', Vol. 40, No. 2, p. 1–12.
==Further reading== * {{Citation |publisher = Encyclopædia Britannica Co. |publication-place = New York |title = Encyclopædia Britannica |publication-date = 1910 |oclc = 14782424 |edition=11th |chapterurl = https://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri19chisrich#page/64/mode/1up |chapter = Museums of Science }}
==External links== {{commons category|Science museums}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20141122220735/https://dir.yahoo.com/science/museums_and_exhibits/ Yahoo directory of science museums] *[http://blogs.nature.com/u6e5b2ce1/2011/02/21/mapping-the-worlds-science-museums Map of the world's science museums from Nature Publishing Group's team blog] *[https://sciencecenternews.wordpress.com Science Center News] *[http://astc.org Association of Science and Technology Centers] *[http://sciencegarage.in The Science Garage]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Science Museum}} [[Category:Science museums| ]] [[Category:Types of museum]]

revision.text:
{{Expert needed|Linguistics|date=November 2008}}
A '''slang dictionary''' is a [[reference book]] containing an [[Alphabetical order|alphabetical]] list of [[slang]], which is [[vernacular]] [[vocabulary]] not generally acceptable in formal usage, usually including information given for each word, including meaning, pronunciation, and [[etymology]]. It can provide definitions on a range of slang from more mundane terms (like "[[Glossary of English language idioms derived from baseball#rain check|rain check]]" or "[[bob and weave]]") to obscure sexual practices. Such works also can include words and phrases arising from different [[dialect]]s and [[argot]]s, which may or may not have passed into more common usage. They can also track the changing meaning of the terms over time and space, as they migrate and mutate. This makes them of interest to a variety of people, from [[Oral history|oral historians]], to [[etymologist]]s, to the casual browser.
== Famous slang dictionaries ==
===17th and 18th centuries=== Slang dictionaries have been around hundreds of years. ''The Canting Academy, or Devil's Cabinet Opened'' was a 17th-century slang dictionary, written in 1673 by [[Richard Head]], that looked to define [[thieves' cant]]. Other early slang dictionaries include ''[[A New Dictionary of the Terms Ancient and Modern of the Canting Crew]]'', first published circa 1698, and [[Francis Grose]]'s ''A Classical Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue'', first published in 1785. Grose's work was arguably the most significant English-language slang dictionary until [[John Camden Hotten]]'s 1859 ''[[A Dictionary of Modern Slang, Cant, and Vulgar Words]]''.<ref>[[Tony Thorne]] (2000) "Slang and the Dictionary".</ref>
===Modern times=== In recent years, dictionaries with a more academic focus have tried to bring together etymological studies in an attempt to provide definitive guides to slang while avoiding problems arising from [[folk etymology]] and [[false etymology]]. The study of slang is now taken seriously by academics, especially [[Lexicography|lexicographers]] like the late [[Eric Partridge]], devoting their energies to the field and publishing on it, including producing slang dictionaries.
===Examples=== * ''[[Green's Dictionary of Slang]]'' (by [[Jonathon Green]], Chambers, {{ISBN|978-0-550-10440-3}}), 2010 comprising three volumes: A-E; F-O; P-Z * ''Chambers Slang Dictionary'' (by [[Jonathon Green]], [[Chambers Harrap|Chambers Harrap Publishers]], {{ISBN|978-0-550-10439-7}}), 2008 previously ''Cassell Dictionary of Slang'' ([[Orion Publishing Group|Cassell Reference]], 1998; last edition 2006, {{ISBN|978-0-304-36636-1}}) *''[[Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English]]'' (by [[Eric Partridge]] and Paul Beale, [[Routledge]], 2002, {{ISBN|0-415-29189-5}}) *''The Oxford Dictionary of Modern Slang'' (by John Ayto and [[John Simpson (lexicographer)|John Simpson]], [[Oxford University Press]], 2005, {{ISBN|0-19-861052-1}})
===Vulgar slang=== There have also been a subsequent amount of [[tongue-in-cheek]] efforts which tend to focus on the more vulgar slang terms: *''[[Roger's Profanisaurus]] Rex: The Ultimate Swearing Dictionary'' (third edition, ''[[Viz (comics)|Viz]]'', 2005, {{ISBN|0-7522-2812-9}})
The [[Urban Dictionary]] relies on user contributions, which can introduce both humour and inaccuracies. It has also been published in book form:
*''Urban Dictionary: Fularious Street Slang Defined'' (by Aaron Peckham, [[Andrews McMeel Publishing|Andrews McMeel]], 2006, {{ISBN|0-7407-5143-3}})
== See also == * [[Jargon]] * [[Thieves' cant]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == {{wikisource|A Dictionary of Slang, Jargon & Cant}} * British Library ''Texts in Context'': [http://www.bl.uk/learning/langlit/dic/grose/vulgar1785.html 1785 – Grose's Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue] {{Gutenberg|no=5402|name=A Classical Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue}} * [http://www.fromoldbooks.org/Grose-VulgarTongue/ fromoldbooks.org version of the Vulgar Tongue with one page per entry, links to examples and to another canting (thieving) dictionary] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070811012922/http://fromoldbooks.org/NathanBailey-CantingDictionary/transcription A 1737 dictionary of canting slang produced by Nathan Bailey] * [http://www.fromoldbooks.org/Farmer-MusaPedestris Three Centuries of Canting Songs and Slang Rhyme, edited by John Farmer (1896)] * [http://www.bl.uk/learning/langlit/dic/head/canting1673.html British Library article on ''The Canting Academy'']
[[Category:Dictionaries by type]] [[Category:Cant languages| ]] [[Category:Slang|Dictionary]] [[Category:Linguistics books]] [[Category:Slang dictionaries| ]]
