revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox book | name = Thomas Aquinas Dictionary | image = Thomas Aquinas Dictionary.jpg | caption = | author = Morris Stockhammer (editor)
Theodore E. James (introduction) | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = Philosophy/Theology | genre = | publisher = [[Philosophical Library]] | pub_date = 1965 | pages = 219 | awards = | isbn = | oclc = 265433 | dewey = | congress = }} The '''''Thomas Aquinas Dictionary''''' is a collection of quotations by medieval philosopher and theologian [[Thomas Aquinas]], indexed by keywords contained within the quotations. Most of the quotations are taken from the ''[[Summa Theologica]]'', with additional material from the ''[[Summa contra Gentiles]]''. The quotations are listed without additional commentary or explanatory notes, although the volume does contain an introduction to the work of Thomas Aquinas written by Theodore E. James. Scholarly reviews were critical of the work when it was published, particularly in terms of the selection and arrangement of material. The book does, however, still appear in bibliographies of reference material on Thomas Aquinas. ==Overview== The ''Thomas Aquinas Dictionary'' was published by the [[Philosophical Library]] in 1965, with a British edition published the same year by Vision. It is one of a series of quotation dictionaries compiled by editor Morris Stockhammer, the others covering [[Immanuel Kant]], [[Karl Marx]] and [[Plato]]. The ''Dictionary'' contains quotations from the works of Thomas Aquinas, arranged under an alphabetical list of keywords, beginning with "Abstinence" and ending with "Zeal". Each entry lists quotations containing the word; the length of the quotations is generally one sentence. The dictionary does not contain any additional commentary or explanatory notes, with the exception of the introduction by Theodore E. James, which contains a summary of the life and works of Thomas Aquinas. Most of the quotations are taken from the ''[[Summa Theologica]]'', Aquinas's best-known work, with others from the ''[[Summa contra Gentiles]]''. The keywords were selected on the basis of being of interest to the twentieth-century student, omitting some medieval concepts. ==Reception== Since its publication, the ''Dictionary'' has been frequently cited in bibliographies of recommended reference works on the life of Thomas Aquinas, although it attracted criticism in scholarly reviews when it was first published, mainly due to the selection and arrangement of material. Vernon Bourke wrote a particularly dismissive review in the medieval history journal ''[[Speculum (journal)|Speculum]]'', asserting that "scholars need not concern themselves with this so-called dictionary". He was especially concerned about the quotations being printed without context or commentary, thus limiting their usefulness or potentially altering their meaning. Hans Bynagle, in his 21st-century guide to philosophical reference material, ''Philosophy: A Guide to the Reference Literature'', echoed these concerns, pointing to the entry for "horse and donkey", which states: "Horse and Donkey are different beings, but both are animals". Bynagle also commented that, due to the keyword method of indexing used, the work lacks headings for concepts which would normally appear in discussions of Aquinas, such as "[[Ontology]]", "[[via negativa]]" or "[[Quinquae viae|The Five Ways]]". A reviewer in ''[[The Review of Metaphysics]]'' (signed "J. K.") similarly pointed to the absence of Christian theological terms such as "[[Redemption (theology)|Redemption]]", "[[Incarnation (Christianity)|Incarnation]]" and "[[Trinity]]". J.K. did highlight, however, the value of the dictionary in containing "an impressive number of entries most of which get several important text references". For him, the introduction was one of the strongest parts of the ''Dictionary'', a view shared by others; even Bourke, who was otherwise critical of the work, described it as "competent". ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite journal|last=Bourke|first=Vernon J.|title=Thomas Aquinas Dictionary by Morris Stockhammer|journal=[[Speculum (journal)|Speculum]]| date=October 1965 |volume=40|issue=4|page=756|jstor=2851435|doi=10.2307/2851435}} {{cite book|last=Bynagle|first=Hans Edward|title=Philosophy: A Guide to the Reference Literature|year=2006|publisher=Libraries Unlimited|isbn=9781563089541|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gN6_6oSSkTAC|page=162}} {{cite book|last=Carlson|first=John W.|title=Words of Wisdom: A Philosophical Dictionary for the Perennial Tradition|year=2012|publisher=University of Notre Dame Press|isbn=978-0-268-02370-6|page=18}} {{cite book|last=McCabe|first=James Patrick|title=Catholic References Sources: A Critical Study|year=1968|publisher=University of Michigan|pages=215–216}} {{cite journal|title=Thomas Aquinas Dictionary by Morris Stockhammer|journal=[[The Review of Metaphysics]]|date=December 1966|volume=20|issue=2|jstor=20124304|page=386}} }} ==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=gN6_6oSSkTAC&pg=PA162&lpg=PA162&dq=%22thomas+aquinas+dictionary%22&source=bl&ots=dMIb616NB7&sig=Vrfy_DH5bPxsmsGmQ09YGaZWYFA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=vdf8UKCBI4nyigLohYHwBw&ved=0CGYQ6AEwCTgU#v=onepage&q=%22thomas%20aquinas%20dictionary%22&f=false Bynagle review of ''Thomas Aquinas Dictionary''] [[Category:English-language books]] [[Category:Books of quotations]] [[Category:1965 books]] [[Category:Books about Thomas Aquinas]] [[Category:Dictionaries of philosophy]]

[[File:Wikipedia mobile app, article for ammonite in Japanese.jpg|thumb|[[List of Wikipedia mobile applications|Wikipedia mobile app]], article for [[ammonite]] in [[Japanese language|Japanese]] in front of an ammonite at the [[Natural History Museum, London]]]]
A museum is defined by the [[International Council of Museums]] (ICOM) as a 'non-profit, permanent institution in the service of society and its development, open to the public, which acquires, conserves, researches, communicates and exhibits the tangible and intangible heritage of humanity and its environment for the purposes of education, study and enjoyment'. A '''virtual museum''' ('''VM''') (according to the ViMM.1 working definition<ref>https://www.vi-mm.eu/2018/01/10/the-vimm-definition-of-a-virtual-museum/</ref>) is a digital entity that draws on the characteristics of a museum, in order to complement, enhance, or augment the museum through personalization, interactivity, user experience and richness of content.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= |title=Virtual museum system evaluation through user studies |journal=Journal of Cultural Heritage |date=2017|volume=26|pages=101–108 |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1296207416303016}}</ref> Both the 'physical' museum (PhM) and the VM share a common commitment to the institutional validation of content and quality of experience through curatorial process, inherent in the ICOM definition.
As with a traditional museum, a virtual museum can be designed around specific objects (such as an art museum or a natural history museum), or can consist of online exhibitions created from primary or secondary resources (as, for example in a science museum). Moreover, a virtual museum can refer to the mobile or [[World Wide Web]] offerings of traditional museums (e.g., displaying digital representations of its collections or exhibits); or can be [[born digital]] content such as, [[3D modeling|3D environments]], [[net art]], [[virtual reality]] and [[digital art]]. Often, discussed in conjunction with other cultural institutions, a museum by definition, is essentially separate from its sister institutions such as a library or an archive. Virtual museums are usually, but not exclusively delivered electronically when they are denoted as online museums, hypermuseum, digital museum, cybermuseums or web museums.
==Early pioneers (CD-ROM and digital media before 2000)== The following museums were created with digital technology before the web gained any form of popularity or mass usability. CD-ROM and postal mail distribution made these museums available world-wide, before web browsers, fast connections and ubiquitous web usage.
* The Virtual Museum, Apple Computer. Released as a CD-ROM in 1992, and distributed free worldwide to 1000 schools, universities and museums, The Virtual Museum was an interactive, electronic museum where users moved from room to room, and selected any exhibit in a room for more detailed examination. The exhibits in the museum were educational, encompassing topics such as medicine, plant growth, the environment, and space. To facilitate interaction with the museum, a new method for navigating through a prerendered 3D space, and interacting with objects in that space had been developed, called 'virtual navigation'. Virtual navigation employed real-time video decompression for the display of, and interaction with, high-quality computer animation. In addition, a representation for 3D objects in animated sequences was used which permitted pixel-accurate, frame-accurate object picking, so that a viewer was able to select any 3D object to trigger movement within the 3D space, to examine an exhibit in animated form, or to play a digital movie or soundtrack. The use of precomputed video permitted 3D navigation in a realistic-looking space, without requiring special-purpose graphics hardware. This was designed as a project to showcase new techniques in computer graphics at the time, particularly to push the envelope of what [[QuickTime]] was capable of, as it was still in [[Betaware|beta]]. This project was the grandfather of [[QuickTime VR]], which made sense given Eric Chen's role in the project. The Virtual Museum was a product of Apple Computer, Inc.'s 3D graphics group and was created by Gavin Miller, Eric Hoffert, Shenchang Eric Chen, Elizabeth Patterson, Dean Blackketter, Steve Rubin, Sally Applin, Derrick Yim and Jim Hanan under the leadership of Frank Crow.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/vis.4340030305/abstract|title=The virtual museum: Interactive 3D navigation of a multimedia database|doi=10.1002/vis.4340030305|volume=3|journal=The Journal of Visualization and Computer Animation|pages=183–197|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150913032532/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/vis.4340030305/abstract|archivedate=2015-09-13|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorgavin.com/Apple/Virtual_Museum.html|title=Virtual Museum|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303232522/http://www.doctorgavin.com/Apple/Virtual_Museum.html|archivedate=2016-03-03|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/The-Virtual-Museum/dp/B003RFDH8W|title=The Virtual Museum: Amazon.com: Books|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305032317/http://www.amazon.com/The-Virtual-Museum/dp/B003RFDH8W|archivedate=2016-03-05|df=}}</ref> * Guggenheim Virtual Museum. In 1999, the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation]] released an experimental interactive virtual museum, conceived by the American design office [[Asymptote Architecture]] and based on VRML technology, to provide a virtual hub for the various venues of the foundation around the world, as well as to host exhibitions of [[cyberart]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Bianchini|first=Riccardo|url=https://www.inexhibit.com/case-studies/virtual-museums-part-1-the-origins/|title=When museums became virtual – Part 1: the origins|publisher=Inexhibit magazine|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160920093137/https://www.inexhibit.com/case-studies/virtual-museums-part-1-the-origins/|archivedate=2016-09-20|df=}}</ref>
==Pioneers (online before 2000)== The following online museums were pioneers. At that time, [[web page]]s were simpler, [[Bandwidth (computing)|bandwidth]] was slower, the concepts of the online museum were still developing, and there were limited [[multimedia]] technologies available within [[web browser]]s. Some online museums began in other (not web site) electronic forms, or were established by existing physical museums. Some online museums have become significant sources of scholarly information, including extensive [[citation]]s within [[Wikipedia]].
* Museum of Computer Art (MOCA) – Founded 1993. Directed by Don Archer, a non-profit corporation under charter from the Department of Education of New York State (US). MOCA was awarded .museum top-level domain (TLD) status by the Museum Domain Management Association (MuseDoma) in 2002 and is hosted on the Web. * Web Museum, Paris – founded online in 1994. A pioneering virtual or web museum is the Web Museum, created by Nicholas Pioch. It is hosted by [[ibiblio]].<ref>[http://www.ibiblio.org/wm/ Web Museum, Paris] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051001014459/http://www.ibiblio.org/wm/ |date=2005-10-01 }}, ibiblio.org.</ref> * The [[Lin Hsin Hsin Art Museum]] – online 1994. An early virtual art museum website by the Singaporean artist [[Lin Hsin Hsin]]. * [[Museum of the History of Science, Oxford|The Museum of the History of Science in Oxford]] – opened 1683, online 21 August 1995. The Museum of the History of Science was the earliest physical museum to inaugurate a programme of virtual exhibitions with detailed collections-based content and high resolution images of artefacts. Located in the oldest surviving purpose-built museum building in the world, it was able to initiate a website relatively early because of the networking facilities and expertise available in the university environment.<ref>[[Jonathan P. Bowen]], Jim Angus, [[Jim Bennett (historian)|Jim Bennett]], Ann Borda, Alpay Beler , [[Andrew Hodges]], and Silvia Filippini-Fantoni, [https://web.archive.org/web/20050326205034/http://www.jpbowen.com/pub/evsc05b.pdf The Development of Science Museum Websites: Case Studies]. In Leo Tan Wee Hin and Ramanathan Subramaniam (eds.), ''[http://www.igi-global.com/Bookstore/TitleDetails.aspx?TitleId=313&DetailsType=Description E-learning and Virtual Science Centers]'', Section 3: Case Studies, Chapter XVIII, pages 366–392. [[Idea Group Publishing]], Hershey, US, 2005.</ref><ref>Jonathan P. Bowen, Jim Bennett, and James Johnson, [http://www.archimuse.com/mw98/papers/bowen/bowen_paper.html Virtual Visits to Virtual Museums] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101104220242/http://www.archimuse.com/mw98/papers/bowen/bowen_paper.html |date=2010-11-04 }}. In Jennifer Trant and David Bearman (eds.), ''Proc. [[Museums and the Web]] [http://www.archimuse.com/mw98/ 1998] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121182036/http://www.archimuse.com/mw98/ |date=2010-11-21 }}'', Toronto, Canada, 22–25 April 1998. CD-ROM, [[Archives & Museum Informatics]], 5501 Walnut Street, Suite 203, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15232-2311, US, 1998.</ref> * Ljubljana: Open-Air Museum – founded 1993 – online 1996. [[Ljubljana]], the [[capital city|capital]] of [[Slovenia]] was presented as a huge [[museum]] where streets were the [[exhibition]]s of the [[architecture]] and building interiors were museum rooms. The method of the presentation were interactive maps and interactive [[virtual reality]] panoramas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.burger.si/Ljubljana/map_Ljubljana_eng.html|title=City View of Ljubljana :: Virtualni sprehod po Ljubljani :: prostorski atlas|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110916134838/http://www.burger.si/Ljubljana/map_Ljubljana_eng.html|archivedate=2011-09-16|df=}}</ref> The aim of the project was to create "3D like" virtual visit of the museum and replacing and documenting the "reality" exhibition after it was discontinued in its original "reality form". After 1996, the project was extended to "Virtual museums of Slovenia", covering all country museums, that is over 106 museum exhibitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.burger.si/SLOMuseums_eng.htm|title=Slovenski muzeji in galerije|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110914111117/http://www.burger.si/SLOMuseums_eng.htm|archivedate=2011-09-14|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burger.si/MuzejiInGalerije/VirtualRealityMuseumsOfSlovenia.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-21 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120413032511/http://www.burger.si/MuzejiInGalerije/VirtualRealityMuseumsOfSlovenia.pdf |archivedate=2012-04-13 |df= }}</ref> Further development of the "Virtual museum"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.si/en/Virtual_Guide_to_Slovene_Museums_and_Galleries|title=Virtual Guide to Slovene Museums and Galleries|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140418220719/http://www.culture.si/en/Virtual_Guide_to_Slovene_Museums_and_Galleries|archivedate=2014-04-18|df=}}</ref> developed to project [[City View]] documenting natural and cultural heritage of the country with over 10.000 locations until year 2006. * [[Virtual Museum of Computing]] – founded 1994.<ref>Jonathan P. Bowen, [http://www.rutherfordjournal.org/article030103.html A Brief History of Early Museums Online] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101031005413/http://www.rutherfordjournal.org/article030103.html |date=2010-10-31 }}, ''[[The Rutherford Journal]]'', [http://www.rutherfordjournal.org/current2.html Volume 3] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101008132830/http://www.rutherfordjournal.org/current2.html |date=2010-10-08 }}, 2010.</ref> This is an eclectic collection of links and online resources concerning the [[history of computers]] and [[History of computer science|computer science]]. * [https://web.archive.org/web/19961106164540/http://www.imj.org.il/ The Israel Museum, Jerusalem] – first launched in 1995, Hebrew pages 1996 * [[Virtual Museum of New France]] – online 1997. Established by the Canadian Museum of Civilization Corporation. * [[Asia Society]] Virtual Gallery – online 1998. Created for the exhibition "More Than Meets the Eye".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sites.asiasociety.org/arts/japanmovie/quicktime.html|title=Asia Society: Japanese Art – Virtual Gallery (QuickTime)|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313233750/http://sites.asiasociety.org/arts/japanmovie/quicktime.html|archivedate=2016-03-13|df=}}</ref> * [[Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County|The Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County]] – founded 1910, online 1998. The museum is the largest natural and historical museum in the Western United States and an active research center. * [[WebExhibits]] – founded 1999, online 1999. WebExhibits is an interactive, web-based museum that encourages visitors to think about and explore scientific and cultural phenomena in new ways.<ref>Michael Douma (2000). [http://www.archimuse.com/mw2000/papers/douma/douma.html Lessons learned from WebExhibits.org: Practical suggestions for good design] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101106102730/http://www.archimuse.com/mw2000/papers/douma/douma.html |date=2010-11-06 }}. In: ''[http://www.archimuse.com/mw2000/ Museums and the Web 2000] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101017030318/http://www.archimuse.com/mw2000/ |date=2010-10-17 }}''. Proceedings. Ed. by David Bearman & Jennifer Trant.</ref> Exhibits include "Investigating Bellini's Feast of the Gods," "Causes of Color," "Color Vision & Art," Pigments through the Ages," "Butter," "Van Gogh's Letters," and "Poetry through the Ages," "Calendars through the Ages," and "Daylight Saving Time." * [[Science Museum (London)|The Science Museum]] in [[London]] – founded 1857, online 1999. One of the major science museums in the world was able to establish an early web presence partly due to the proximity of [[Imperial College]], but was also spurred on by the fact that the [[Natural History Museum, London|Natural History Museum]], which is next door, had recently established the first dedicated museum web server in the [[United Kingdom]]. * The Thylacine Museum – online 1999. The Thylacine Museum<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naturalworlds.org/thylacine/|title=The Thylacine Museum – A Natural History of the Tasmanian Tiger|publisher=}}</ref> is an online scientific and educational resource aimed at promoting a greater awareness and understanding of the biology, behaviour and history of the [[thylacine]], or Tasmanian tiger (''Thylacinus cynocephalus''). * [[ibiblio]] – founded 1992, online 2000. An online exhibition with the backing of the [[Library of Congress]], ibiblio hosted EXPO Ticket Office<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/expo/|title=EXPO Ticket Office|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051001004211/http://ibiblio.org/expo/|archivedate=2005-10-01|df=}}</ref> with exhibits including a Vatican Exhibit<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/expo/vatican.exhibit/Vatican.exhibit.html|title=Vatican Exhibit|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050916060441/http://www.ibiblio.org/expo/vatican.exhibit/Vatican.exhibit.html|archivedate=2005-09-16|df=}}</ref> and even a virtual "restaurant"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/expo/restaurant/restaurant.html|title=EXPO Restaurant Le Cordon Bleu|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050917113406/http://www.ibiblio.org/expo/restaurant/restaurant.html|archivedate=2005-09-17|df=}}</ref> and "post office".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/expo/expo/postoffice.html|title=EXPO Post Office|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060227080147/http://www.ibiblio.org/expo/expo/postoffice.html|archivedate=2006-02-27|df=}}</ref> This looks very simplistic now, but was novel in 1991.
==Other online museums== Most physical museums now have an online presence, with varying degrees of online information. At one end of the spectrum, museums provide simple contact and background information, and a listing of exhibitions (brochure museums). On the other end of the spectrum are museums that exist only online, or those that have a physical building but offer extensive online exhibits, interactive online features, multimedia, and searchable or browsable collections (content museums, learning museums, virtual museums).<ref>Schweibenz, Werner. "The Development of Virtual Museums". ICOMNEWS. no. 3. 2004.</ref>
The following are a few other museums online: * [[UMA - Universal Museum of Art]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.the-uma.org|title=UMA – Universal Museum of Art|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130506193818/http://the-uma.org|archivedate=2013-05-06|df=}}</ref> is an online-only museum which launched 2017. It has the ambition to work universal in virtual reality and is based on two principles: accessibility and innovation. UMA is offering exhibitions through the world art history, it's not connected to one top topic, country or region. * [[DiMoDA]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dimoda.art|title=DiMoDA – The Digital Museum of Digital Art|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180104194051/https://dimoda.art/|archivedate=2018-01-04|df=}}</ref> is an online and touring museum of digital and virtual reality art. DiMoDA hosts exhibitions in partnership with galleries and museums around the world and features previous exhibitions as online downloads from their website. * [[International Museum of Women]] is an online-only museum that does not have a physical building and instead offers online exhibitions about women's issues globally as well as an online community. Online exhibitions include "Imagining Ourselves" (launched 2006) about women's identity, "Women, Power and Politics" (2008), and "Economica: Women and the Global Economy" (2009). * [[Girl Museum]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.girlmuseum.org|title=Girl Museum – Virtual Museum Celebrating Girlhood|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140207092338/http://www.girlmuseum.org/|archivedate=2014-02-07|df=}}</ref> is an online-only museum that does not have a physical building and instead offers online exhibitions that celebrate [[girl]]hood in the past and present. Also offers educational guides, collaborative projects through social media, and a podcast series. Launched 2009. * [[Tucson LGBTQ Museum]] is an online-only museum that does not have a physical building and instead offers online exhibitions about LGBTQ history. The online photographic, audio, video, text, and other historical exhibitions include exhibits from the 1700s to the present day. The effort began in the summer of 1967 and spanned almost 50 years. {{cn|date=February 2018}} * [[International New Media Gallery]] (INMG) is an online museum specialising in moving image and screen-based art. The INMG is dedicated to exploring current debates and topics in art history: touching on areas such as migration, war, environmental activism and the internet itself. The gallery publishes extensive academic catalogues alongside its exhibitions. It also hosts spaces for discussion and debate, both online and offline. * [[Google Art Project]] is an online compilation of high-resolution images of artworks from galleries worldwide, as well as a virtual tour of the galleries in which they are housed. The project was launched on 1 February 2011 by [[Google]], and includes works in the [[Tate Gallery]], [[London]]; the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], [[New York City]]; and the [[Uffizi]], [[Florence]].<ref>{{cite journal | title = Google Art Project: 'Street view' technology added to museums | journal = [[The Washington Post]], Arts Post | date = 2011-02-01 | first = Philip | last = Kennicott | id = | url = http://voices.washingtonpost.com/arts-post/2011/02/google_launches_the_google_art.html | accessdate = 2011-08-25 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6621Uf84l?url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/arts-post/2011/02/google_launches_the_google_art.html | archivedate = 2012-03-09 | df = }}</ref> * [[USAF Police Online Museum & Memorial]] – The [[Department of the Air Force Police|USAF]] Police Alumni Association operates the USAF Police Virtual Museum & Memorial.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usafpolice.org|title=USAF Police Alumni Association – US Air Force Security Forces – Virtual Museum – Memorial – Military Police – USAF – SP – AP – SF|work=USAF Police Alumni Association|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170613123550/http://www.usafpolice.org/|archivedate=2017-06-13|df=}}</ref> * [[Virtual Museum of Modern Nigerian Art]] – the VMMNA is the first of its kind in Africa. Hosted by the [[Pan-African University, Lagos]], Nigeria this virtual museum offers a good view of the development on Nigerian Art in the past fifty years. * [[United Kingdom|UK's]] [[Culture24]] – online guide to public museums, galleries, libraries, archives, heritage sites and science centres in the United Kingdom. * [[Virtual Museum of Canada]] – [[Canada]]'s national virtual museum. With over 2,500 Canadian museums, the VMC brings together Canada's museums regardless of size or geographical location. * [[Museum With No Frontiers]] – The Virtual Museum set up by MWNF was launched in 2005. It is a real museum, including a Collection, Exhibitions and a Database, and is the result of international cooperation between museums and cultural heritage organisations, based on the MWNF methodology. So far, three thematic museums have been completed: Discover Islamic Art (www.discoverislamicart.org) (online since 2005, Database of 2,113 objects and monuments from 22 countries, 19 Virtual Exhibitions); Discover Baroque Art (www.discoverbaroqueart.org) (online since 2010, Database of 588 objects and monuments from 7 countries, 9 Virtual Exhibitions), and Sharing History (www.sharinghistory.org) (focusing on Arab-Ottoman-European relations between 1815 and 1918, online since 2015, Database of 2,636 objects and monuments from 22 countries, 10 Virtual Exhibitions). * [[Carnamah Historical Society]] – an Australian historical society whose ''Virtual Museum: to be known and distinguished as Carnamah'' won a Museums and Galleries National Award in 2014.<ref>[http://www.museumsaustralia.org.au/site/magna2014_winners.php "MAGNA 2014 Winners". Museums Australia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030223311/http://www.museumsaustralia.org.au/site/magna2014_winners.php |date=2014-10-30 }}. Retrieved 8 November 2014</ref> * [[Virtual Museum of Soviet Repression in Belarus]] – The museum presents recordings of audio- and video-recollections of witnesses of Soviet repression in Belarus. The museum is operated by historians and other scientists from Belarus, based on a private initiative. It started collection of materials in 2007 and is operable since 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://represii.net/|title=Музей савецкіх рэпрэсій|work=Музей савецкіх рэпрэсій|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150524135655/http://represii.net/|archivedate=2015-05-24|df=}}</ref> * [[Western Australian Museum]] – CyberMuseum using social media sites of [[Twitter]] and [[Facebook]] to tell the history of Perth, Western Australia, through photographs, videos and news feeds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.6pr.com.au/blogs/6pr-perth-blog/perths-online-memory-lane/20140225-33fey.html|title=Perth's online memory lane|work=6PR|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714164855/http://www.6pr.com.au/blogs/6pr-perth-blog/perths-online-memory-lane/20140225-33fey.html|archivedate=2014-07-14|df=|access-date=2014-07-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2013/04/08/3732116.htm|title=Uncovering old Perth through new networks|work=ABC Perth|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714235307/http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2013/04/08/3732116.htm|archivedate=2014-07-14|df=}}</ref> * [[St George's Museum]], founded in Walkley near Sheffield in 1875 by the Victorian art critic [[John Ruskin]] and later dispersed, has been recreated as a virtual museum by the "Ruskin at Walkley" project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ruskinatwalkley.org/|title=Ruskin at Walkley|website=www.ruskinatwalkley.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170706022159/https://www.ruskinatwalkley.org/|archivedate=2017-07-06|df=}}</ref> * [[The Archive of Digital Art]], founded in 1999, launched a Light Box tool in 2014, which is utilized a.o. for the display of historic media art exhibitions and collaborative curatorial concepts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalartarchive.at/nc/home.html|title=Home – ADA {{!}} Archive of Digital Art|website=www.digitalartarchive.at|language=en-EN|access-date=2017-04-20|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170331181530/http://www.digitalartarchive.at/nc/home.html|archivedate=2017-03-31|df=}}</ref> * [[National Portal and Digital Repository for Museums of India]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.museumsofindia.gov.in/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-05-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170625225042/http://museumsofindia.gov.in/ |archivedate=2017-06-25 |df= }}</ref> is designed and developed by [[Human-Centred Design and Computing Group]] of [[Centre for Development of Advanced Computing]] (C-DAC), India<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cdac.in/index.aspx?id=mc_hc_nation_digi_repo_portal_museum|title=National Digital Repository and Portal for Museums of India|website=cdac.in|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180221183649/https://cdac.in/index.aspx?id=mc_hc_nation_digi_repo_portal_museum|archivedate=2018-02-21|df=}}</ref> in collaboration and with funding support from Ministry of Culture, Government of India. The National Portal for Museums of India was formally launched on 21 October 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaculture.nic.in/launch-national-portal-museums-india|title=Launch of National Portal of Museums of India – Ministry of Culture, Government of India|website=www.indiaculture.nic.in}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=110752|title=Union Minister of State for Culture and Tourism, Shri Shripad Naik launches the National Portal for Museums|website=pib.nic.in|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180221183650/http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=110752|archivedate=2018-02-21|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/pune/report-love-visiting-museums-they-are-just-a-click-away-1970395|title=Love visiting museums? They are just a click away – Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|date=19 March 2014|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180221183649/http://www.dnaindia.com/pune/report-love-visiting-museums-they-are-just-a-click-away-1970395|archivedate=21 February 2018|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/pune/Take-a-virtual-tour-of-10-national-museums/articleshow/32688618.cms|title=Take a virtual tour of 10 national museums – Times of India|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161201153142/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/pune/Take-a-virtual-tour-of-10-national-museums/articleshow/32688618.cms|archivedate=2016-12-01|df=}}</ref>The portal offers search & retrieval and integrated access to digitized collections of 10 national museums namely National Museum of India, New Delhi; Allahabad Museum, Allahabad; Indian Museum, Kolkata; National Gallery of Modern Arts (NGMA), New Delhi; National Gallery of Modern Arts (NGMA), Mumbai; National Gallery of Modern Arts (NGMA), Bengaluru; Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) Museum, Goa; Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) Museum, Nagarjunakonda; Salar Jung Museum, Hyderabad and Victoria Memorial Hall, Kolkata. All participating museums are using [[JATAN: Virtual Museum Builder]], a software developed by C-DAC<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cdac.in/index.aspx?id=mc_hc_jatan_virtual_museum|title=Jatan virtual museum builder|website=cdac.in|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180221183650/https://cdac.in/index.aspx?id=mc_hc_jatan_virtual_museum|archivedate=2018-02-21|df=}}</ref>for the purpose of standardization. The National Portal for Museums of India also won Special Mention Grand Jury Manthan Award in e-Culture, Heritage & Tourism category in 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://manthanaward.org/e-culture-heritage-tourism-winner/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-05-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318063520/http://manthanaward.org/e-culture-heritage-tourism-winner/ |archivedate=2017-03-18 |df= }}</ref> * [[Internetmuseum]] – a Swedish digital museum opened in 2014. The ambition of the museum is to spread knowledge of the [[History of the Internet in Sweden|Swedish history of Internet]] and to preserve the digital heritage.<ref>{{cite web|title=Swedish "internet museum" investigates our digital past|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2054&artikel=6038467|publisher=Sveriges Radio|accessdate=7 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108205437/http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2054&artikel=6038467|archivedate=8 November 2017|df=}}</ref>
==Research and scholarship== The digitalization of museums is a task that has combined efforts, budgets and research from many museums, cultural associations and governments around the world. For the last few years, there have been projects related to [[Information Society Technologies]] dealing with: preservation of [[cultural heritage]], restoration and learning resources. Some examples of contributions in the field of digital and virtual museography: Euromuse.net (EU), DigiCULT (EU), Musings, Digital Museums Projects. European Community has founded various projects to support this filed, like V-Must, the Virtual Museum Transnational Network that aims to provide the heritage sector with the tools and support to develop Virtual Museums that are educational, enjoyable, long-lasting and easy to maintain.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.v-must.net/ |title= V-MUST: Virtual Museum Transnational Network; a EU FP7-funded Network of Excellence |accessdate= 2013-03-21 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130428035401/http://v-must.net/ |archivedate= 2013-04-28 |df= }}</ref>
In 2017, Virtual Multimodal Museum [http://www.vi-mm.eu (ViMM)] continues to explore the core concept of the virtual museum where the [http://www.vi-mm.eu/2017/03/21/working-group-1-1-what-is-a-virtual-museum/ Working group 1.1] is actively working towards re-defining the definition of the virtual museum in order to keep up with current research.
The leading international conference in the field of museums and their websites is the annual ''[[Museums and the Web]]'' conference.
In 2004, Roy Hawkey of [[King's College London]] reported that "Virtual visitors to museum websites already out-number physical (on-site) visitors, and many of these are engaged in dedicated learning".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://archive.futurelab.org.uk/resources/publications-reports-articles/literature-reviews/Literature-Review205 | title = Learning with digital technologies in museums, science centres and galleries | accessdate = 2011-08-25 | last = Hawkey | first = Roy | date = September 2004 | publisher = Futurelab | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120225002902/http://archive.futurelab.org.uk/resources/publications-reports-articles/literature-reviews/Literature-Review205 | archivedate = 2012-02-25 | df = }}</ref>
In establishing virtuality and promoting cultural development, the goal is not merely to reproduce existing objects, but to actualize new ones. Information and communication technologies are not merely tools for processing data and making it available, but can be a force and stimulus for cultural development.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Elisa Giaccardi | title = Collective Storytelling and Social Creativity in the Virtual Museum: A Case Study | journal = [[Design Issues]] | volume = 22 | issue = 3 | pages = 29–41 | date = 2006 | doi=10.1162/desi.2006.22.3.29}}</ref>
==Interactive environments== There are several types of interactive environments. One is to re-create 3D space with visual representations of the museum by a 3D architectural metaphor, which provides a sense of place using various spatial references. They usually use [[3D computer graphics|3D modelling]], VRML ([[VRML|Virtual Reality Modelling Language]]) and now [[X3D]](successor to VRML) for viewing. There have been introduced various kinds of imaging techniques for building virtual museums, such as infrared reflectography, [[X-ray]] imaging, 3D [[laser scanning]], IBMR (Image Based Rendering and Modeling) techniques. In the case of EU-funded projects, the [[ViHAP3D]], a new virtual reality system for scanning museum artifacts, has been developed by EU researchers.{{citation needed|date=November 2010}} Another interactive three-dimensional spatial environment is [[QTVR]]. Being a pre-rendered, fixed environment it is more restricted in regards to moving freely around in 3D space but the image quality can be superior to that of real-time rendered environments. This was especially the case in the mid-1990s when computing power and online speeds were limited.
==Mobile telepresence== In 2013, the [[National Museum of Australia]] and the Australian [[Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation]] (CSIRO) trialled a virtual museum tour system that uses mobile [[telepresence]] technology and requires a high-speed broadband connection. The technology allows remote visitors, for example school students from regional and remote Australia, to interact with a museum facilitator through a robot equipped with an omni-directional camera. Each remote visitor is able to control their own view of the museum gallery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nma.gov.au/education-kids/mobile-telepresence|title=National Museum of Australia – Robot tours|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420044316/http://www.nma.gov.au/education-kids/mobile-telepresence|archivedate=2013-04-20|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csiro.au/Organisation-Structure/Divisions/ICT-Centre/Museum-Robot.aspx|title=Museum Robot: CSIRO|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130316145657/http://www.csiro.au/Organisation-Structure/Divisions/ICT-Centre/Museum-Robot.aspx|archivedate=2013-03-16|df=|access-date=2013-04-15}}</ref><ref>[http://www.computerworld.com.au/article/456904/csiro_telepresence_robots_connect_students_national_museum/ 'CSIRO telepresence robots connect students with National Museum', ''Computerworld'', 21 March 2013] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420071250/http://www.computerworld.com.au/article/456904/csiro_telepresence_robots_connect_students_national_museum/ |date=20 April 2013 }}</ref>
==Domain names== Museums have a variety of [[top-level domain]] names. In the United States, many are [[.org]]. Some are [[.gov]], or governmental domains for other countries. A few are [[.edu]] in the US, either as part of a larger educational institution, or grandfathered in when .edu regulations changed (e.g., as with the [[Exploratorium]]). The ''[[.museum]]'' domain name is used by some museums, as organized by [[MuseDoma]], but is not widely used.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://index.museum/generic.php?domain=virtual.museum|title=Search result in the .museum Registry|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050802090820/http://index.museum/generic.php?domain=virtual.museum|archivedate=2005-08-02|df=}}</ref>
== Prospects of development == Depending on the scientific position of the researchers, industry or instrumental use, virtual museums are regarded and used in different ways. For example, as a kind of creative activity; an innovative educational tool; a fashion or advertising project; а room with multimedia capabilities; the representation of the traditional Museum on the Internet; a gadget; the publication; website; type of communication; the electronic catalogue, etc.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Maksimova|first1=Tatiana|title=Virtual museums: an analytical review of foreign publications|url=http://cyberleninka.ru/article/n/virtualnye-muzei-analiticheskiy-obzor-zarubezhnyh-publikatsiy|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170510093550/http://cyberleninka.ru/article/n/virtualnye-muzei-analiticheskiy-obzor-zarubezhnyh-publikatsiy|archivedate=2017-05-10|df=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Virtual Library museums pages]] * [[Museology]] (also called museum studies), the study of how to organize and manage museums and museum collections * [[Mobile museums]] – a different kind of mobile museum, when a museum is on an RV and drives to audiences
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Commons category-inline}}

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; remove 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox Magazine |title = What Will They Learn? |image_file = |image_size = |image_caption = |editor = Michael Poliakoff |staff_writer = |frequency = Annual |circulation = |category = [[Higher education]] |company = |publisher = [[American Council of Trustees and Alumni]] |firstdate = 2009 |country = [[United States]] |language = [[English language|English]] |website = {{url|http://www.whatwilltheylearn.com}} |issn = }} '''''What Will They Learn?''''' is the annual rating system of American [[college]]s and [[University|universities]] published by the [[American Council of Trustees and Alumni]], a [[Washington, D.C.]]-based [[higher education]] non-profit. The report, which evaluates the core academic requirements at over 1,100 public and private universities, has been published annually since 2009.<ref>{{cite news|last=Aldridge|first=James|title=UTSA scores an ‘A’ on its undergraduate education|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanantonio/news/2013/10/29/utsa-scores-an-a-on-its.html|accessdate=31 October 2013|newspaper=San Antonio Business Journal|date=2013-10-29}}</ref>
==Overview== ''What Will They Learn?'' was first published in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gtrnews.com/greater-tulsa-reporter/10505/usao-joins-us-elite-19-for-a-grade-curriculum|publisher=GTR Newspapers|title=USAO Joins U.S. Elite 19 for ‘A-grade’ Curriculum|date=January 18, 2012|accessdate=May 23, 2012}}</ref><ref name=glenn>{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.com/article/Group-Offers-Alternative/48086/?sid=at|publisher=[[Chronicle of Higher Education]]|title=Group Offers Alternative Rankings Based on Curricula|author=Glenn, David|date=August 19, 2009|accessdate=June 12, 2012}}</ref> The report assigns a letter grade to over 1,100 universities based on how many of the following seven core subjects are required: composition, literature, foreign language, American history, economics, mathematics and science.<ref name=aquinas>{{cite web|url=http://www.thomasaquinas.edu/news/acta-gives-college-highest-possible-academic-ranking|title=ACTA Gives College Highest Possible Academic Ranking|publisher=[[Thomas Aquinas College]]|date=September 1, 2011|accessdate=May 23, 2012}}</ref> ACTA concludes that most of the country's leading universities do not have rigorous general education requirements.<ref name=parker>{{cite web|author=Parker, Kathleen|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/our-unprepared-graduates/2011/09/30/gIQAJGYBBL_story.html|title=Our unprepared graduates|publisher=[[Washington Post]]|date=September 30, 2011|accessdate=May 23, 2012}}</ref>
==Editions==
===2009-2010===
The first edition of the study looked at 100 schools across the nation. Only 5 institutions garnered an "A" rating, whereas 25 earned an "F." Among the "F" institutions were several schools traditionally considered elite, including [[Yale University]].<ref name="williams">{{cite news |first = Walter E. |last = Williams |url = http://www.investors.com/NewsAndAnalysis/Article.aspx?id=504861&Ntt=williams+what+will+they+learn |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130126155037/http://www.investors.com/NewsAndAnalysis/Article.aspx?id=504861&Ntt=williams+what+will+they+learn |dead-url = yes |archive-date = January 26, 2013 |title = What Will They Learn for your $50,000? |work = [[Investor's Business Daily]] |date = August 31, 2009 |accessdate = 6 March 2010 }}</ref>
===2010-2011===
In the 2010-2011 edition, ACTA expanded ''What Will They Learn?'' to include 718 institutions. The grades broke down to 17 "A's" (2%), 252 "B's" (35%), 209 "C's" (29%), 136 "D's" (19%) and 104 "F's" (14%).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/11/19/AR2010111907408.html|title=College ratings ignites debate over core requirements|author=de Vise, Daniel|publisher=[[Washington Post]]|date=November 20, 2010|accessdate=June 13, 2012}}</ref>
===2011-2012===
The 2011-2012 edition of ''What Will They Learn?'' was released on August 30, 2011. The study evaluated the general education requirements of 1,012 colleges and universities. The grade breakdown percentages remained similar to previous years, with 19 schools earning an "A" grade.<ref name=mcgurn>{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204394804577010080547122646|title=What's Your Kid Getting From College? |author=McGurn, William|date=November 1, 2011 |publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=April 9, 2012}}</ref>
===2012-2013===
The 2012-2013 edition of ''What Will They Learn?'' was released in October 2012. The study evaluated 1,070 colleges and universities, with 21 schools earning an "A" grade.<ref>{{cite news|last=Czupor|first=Z.J.|title=National study ranks Colorado Christian in top 2% of colleges|url=http://yourhub.denverpost.com/lakewood/national-study-ranks-colorado-christian-university-top-2/1j3EFzk1CWbTLFU4yJNioN-ugc|accessdate=11 January 2013|newspaper=Denver Post|date=October 11, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130215211303/http://yourhub.denverpost.com/lakewood/national-study-ranks-colorado-christian-university-top-2/1j3EFzk1CWbTLFU4yJNioN-ugc|archivedate=15 February 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=History Literacy Failing Among American Students, Study Faults Colleges Lack Of Core Subject Requirements|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/10/10/study-rates-colleges-base_n_1954987.html|accessdate=11 January 2013|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=2012-10-10}}</ref> [[Regent University]], which received an "A" grade from ACTA, was subsequently awarded $400,000 by the Beazley Foundation in recognition of the school's strong core curriculum.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hutchins|first=Sarah|title=Regent's grade on curriculum lands school $400,000|url=http://www.hamptonroads.com/2012/10/regents-grade-curriculum-lands-school-400000|accessdate=11 January 2013|newspaper=The Virginian-Pilot|date=October 11, 2012}}</ref>
===2013-2014=== The 2013-2014 edition of ''What Will They Learn?'' was released in October 2013. The study evaluated 1,091 colleges and universities, with 22 schools earning an "A" grade.<ref name="gastongazette.com">{{cite news|title=Report gives GWU ‘A’ grade for core subjects|url=http://www.gastongazette.com/news/local/report-gives-gwu-a-grade-for-core-subjects-1.226729|accessdate=30 October 2013|newspaper=Gaston Gazette|date=2013-10-30}}</ref> The 2013-2014 edition included the [[Foundation for Individual Rights in Education|Foundation for Individual Rights in Education's]] campus free speech "Spotlight" rating alongside the What Will They Learn? grades.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.whatwilltheylearn.com/more-to-consider|work=What Will They Learn?|publisher=What Will They Learn?|accessdate=4 November 2013}}</ref>
===2014-2015=== The 2014-2015 edition of the study, which analyzed 1,098 institutions of higher learning, issued 23 "A" grades.<ref name=philly>{{cite news|title=Study: ‘What Will They Learn’ In College? Probably Not Much|url=http://philadelphia.regionsbusiness.com/study-will-learn-college-probably-much/|accessdate=4 March 2015|publisher=Region's Business|date=October 15, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402110824/http://philadelphia.regionsbusiness.com/study-will-learn-college-probably-much/|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=}}</ref>
===2015-2016=== The 2015-2016 edition of the study, which analyzed 1,108 institutions of higher learning, issued 24 "A" grades.<ref>{{cite news|title=What WIll They Learn 2015-16?|url=http://www.goacta.org/publications/what_will_they_learn_2015_16|accessdate=21 December 2015|publisher=American Council of Trustees and Alumni|date=October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Opinion Journal: Dumbing Down Colleges|url=https://www.wsj.com/video/opinion-journal-dumbing-down-colleges/6FB8908F-5991-41EF-9506-A07283225086.html|accessdate=21 December 2015|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=October 6, 2015}}</ref>
===2016-2017=== The 2016-2017 edition of the study, which analyzed over 1,100 institutions of higher learning, assigned 25 "A" grades.<ref>{{cite web|title="A" List|url=http://whatwilltheylearn.com/a-list|publisher=American Council of Trustees and Alumni|accessdate=2 December 2016}}</ref>
==The A-list== The 25 schools on the ''What Will They Learn?'' "A-List" for 2016-2017 include [[Baylor University]], [[Bluefield College]], [[California Polytechnic State University–San Luis Obispo]], [[Christopher Newport University]], [[Clark Atlanta University]], [[Colorado Christian University]], [[Gardner-Webb University]], [[Georgia Southern University]], [[Kennesaw State University]], [[Morehouse College]], [[Pepperdine University]], [[Regent University]], [[St. Katherine College]], [[Southwest Baptist University]], [[St. John's College (Annapolis/Santa Fe)]], [[Thomas Aquinas College]], [[Thomas More College of Liberal Arts]], [[United States Air Force Academy]], [[United States Coast Guard Academy]], [[United States Merchant Marine Academy]], [[United States Military Academy]], [[University of Dallas]], [[University of Georgia]], and [[University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma]].<ref>{{cite web|title="A" List|url=http://whatwilltheylearn.com/a-list|website=What Will They Learn?|publisher=American Council of Trustees and Alumni|accessdate=2 December 2016}}</ref>
==Response==
Nationally syndicated columnist [[Kathleen Parker]] wrote that ''What Will They Learn?'' is a guide that can "help parents and students determine where they might get the best bang for their buck." The study has been featured in the ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'', the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', and newspapers across the [[United States]].<ref name=parker/><ref name=mcgurn/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whatwilltheylearn.com/news|title=In The News|publisher=[[American Council of Trustees and Alumni]]|accessdate=June 13, 2012}}</ref> Upon the report's release in 2009, the founder of ''[[US News and World Report]]'', Mel Elfin, reassured ACTA that the anger of some of the higher education establishment "is probably a sign that you are on the right track [to reform]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://centerforcollegeaffordability.org/archives/1120|title=What Will They Learn?|publisher=Center for College Affordability and Productivity|date=August 19, 2009|accessdate=June 13, 2012}}</ref>
In response to the strong performance of [[historically black colleges and universities]], [[Michael Lomax]], president of the [[United Negro College Fund]], said "the ACTA review’s finding that historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) ‘demonstrate overall stronger general education requirements than other public and private institutions’ confirms the important role these universities continue to play in American higher education.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://whatwilltheylearn.com/public/pdfs/QuoteSheet.pdf | title=Reactions to What Will They Learn? Project | publisher=[[American Council of Trustees and Alumni]]|format=PDF}}</ref>
In 2009, Debra Humphreys, vice president for communications and public affairs at the [[Association of American Colleges and Universities]], said, "as is often the case with [[American Council of Trustees and Alumni|ACTA]], they have posed some very good questions," but Humphreys criticized the study for being narrow in scope and called its methodology "inadequate."<ref name=glenn/>
ACTA countered that claim by commissioning a Roper study in 2011. The study found that 70 percent of Americans agreed with ACTA that all students should be required to take core curriculum classes. That number jumped to 80 percent among 25- to 34-year-olds who, according to the survey, are those "just out of college who may find learnings from such classes are helpful in the job market."<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://whatwilltheylearn.com/public/pdfs/RoperFindings.pdf | title=Roper Study Findings | publisher=[[American Council of Trustees and Alumni]]|format=PDF}}</ref>
[[Murray Sperber]] of [[Indiana University]] said the report "documents higher education's dirty little secret: Schools are charging more each year and requiring many fewer traditional education courses. This results in a legion of students with spotty educations and meaningless degrees."<ref name=glenn/>
